Through engaging seminars and workshops, we create a platform for sharing experiences and insights, fostering an inclusive environment where every voice is valued. What sets us apart is our commitment to volunteerism. Every member of our club contributes their time and expertise to make a positive impact. We believe in the power of meaningful connections and the transformative potential of education, especially during the pivotal high school to university transition. Join us in making a difference, one connection at a time. Together, we can bridge the gap and inspire a new generation of empathetic leaders who understand the importance of lifting others as they climb.

club_info.name: United for Literacy at St. George Student Chapter

detailed_info.club_name: United for Literacy at St. George Student Chapter
detailed_info.description: United for Literacy at U of T St. George is a non-profit, volunteer-run student organization at the University of Toronto. Our program fosters the development of skills in basic literacy, numeracy, and English as a Second Language for elementary, secondary and adult learners. We believe literacy is a right. We work with volunteers and community partners to give people the skills and confidence they need to reach their potential! United for Literacy is active at about 35 university and college campuses from coast to coast. Here at UofT St. George, we run 6 different programs at 4 different locations in downtown Toronto.

club_info.name: United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund: University of Toronto Student Chapter (UNICEF)

detailed_info.club_name: United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund: University of Toronto Student Chapter (UNICEF)
detailed_info.description: U of T UNICEF, a university group directly affiliated with UNICEF Canada, strives to raise funds and promote awareness of issues such as child labour, poverty, gender inequality, illiteracy, HIV/AIDS, and living environment. We operate through our two programs to target both the university community and local youth.

club_info.name: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Project (UNSDG Project)

detailed_info.club_name: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Project (UNSDG Project)
detailed_info.description: The UNSDG Project works to collectively respond to the UN’s 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by engaging student members in direct action, including but not limited to service, fundraising, and advocacy; while utilizing creativity within each initiative. We focus on 1-2 SDGs per 1-2 months (in any desired order), with all initiative planned and executed collectively, sometimes with external organizations or NGOs. Our goal is to create meaningful change on global issues while empowering members with mindsets of global citizens; building momentum for continued, future progress.

The purpose of the wine society is to bring to light the rich and important culture surrounding wine production, distribution, and trends. The club is educational, many of the members have found a lack of education about alcohol, wine in particular can lead to an unhealthy relationship with it. Through learning about the way wine should be looked at, as an artistic expression produced by the earth, we hope to enhance people’s understanding and create a better relationship with alcohol. It is also an asset to know about wine in a business setting, this club can provide members with a foundational education in wines from which they can broaden their understanding of this vast industry. We hope to engage with Canada’s wine producers especially within the southern Ontario region, this is a great outreach opportunity for the university. Events will focus on teaching about different regions of wine production with guest speakers, wine producers and merchants already expressing interest in sharing their thoughts.
UBF is a group to facilitate an interest in Bible study, and provide fellowship opportunities among students, including meetings, seasonal retreats, and conferences.

UCDBC is a dragon boat racing club founded on passion, drive, and resilience. As one of the fastest university teams in Canada across the mixed, open, and women’s divisions, we take pride in fostering a welcoming environment that promotes personal growth and development. We welcome athletes of all skill levels and experience —whether you’re a seasoned paddler or brand new to the sport, there’s a place for you at UCDBC. We are committed to training athletes with equal dedication, helping each individual reach their potential while providing a supportive community to build meaningful friendships. We compete in several regattas during the summer, with our most recent success being the defense of our title as 1st place in the U24 Open division, our 1st gold medal in the U24 Women’s division, and a bronze in the U24 Mixed division at the Canadian National Championships. Additionally, our performance at the international level at the Club Crew World Championships (Ravenna, Italy) earned us 6 out of 9 gold medals across the U24 Open (3/3 gold), Women’s (1/3 gold), and Mixed divisions (2/3 gold), securing our position as the top U24 club in the world. Looking to get started at the gym? During the school year, we provide trainers to help you get stronger and reach your fitness goals. Beyond training, we host a variety of social events and gatherings, as we highly value team bonding. Outside of the team, we actively promote the sport of dragon boat, organize fundraising events, and encourage fitness within our local community. Our goal is to continue excelling as a top-performing dragon boat team, while helping our athletes become the best version of themselves, both in and out of the boat. We hope you’ll join us on this journey. Make Waves. Make History.

Every undergraduate student in University College belongs to the University College Literary and Athletic Society, fondly referred to as the UC Lit. Founded in 1854 and composed of 31 elected student representatives, the UC Lit provides many services, organizes a variety of events, and represents almost 5000 University College students at UofT. No matter where your interests may lie, the UC Lit has something for you. Visit our website to check out what we have to offer!

Created in 1992, the University College Residence Council, or UCRC, is University College’s newest (and thus coolest) student government. While other student governments, such as the University College Literary and Athletic Society, deal with mainly extracurricular activities, only the UCRC deals with issues specific to residence life in University College. The UCRC acts as an umbrella for the individual house councils, and holds numerous residence-wide events. These activities include parties, charity toy drives, environmental awareness campaigns, and resource distribution, just to name a few.

The mission of the University College branch of The PEARS Project at the University of Toronto is to provide support and resources to survivors of gender-based and sexual violence. Our areas of work include social advocacy, mental health advocacy, social justice, sexual health awareness, and activism. As a grassroots, trauma-informed coalition founded and led by survivors, PEARS values survivors as leaders whose voices are essential for driving policy change. By establishing a survivor-led community and resource network, PEARS aims to enhance access to legal, mental health, and capacity-building supports. Collaborating with college branches allows PEARS to foster relationships with broader student communities and promote the efforts of other campus stakeholders.

club_info.name: University of Toronto – Trek for Teens Student Chapter

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto – Trek for Teens Student Chapter
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Trek for Teens Student Chapter will raise funds and awareness for homeless youth, with a particular emphasis on the organizations supported by the Trek for Teens Foundation Inc. The group will support the Trek for Teens Foundation Inc. in their events, campaigns and activities and will provide students with the opportunity to volunteer for local homeless service providers. The group will help students grow through the organization of awareness and fundraising campaigns, activities and events. It will further enable students to reach out to the community, by acting in leadership positions and develop their public speaking skills, primarily through workshops and presentations to post-secondary, high school and elementary level students.

club_info.name: UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO 021 ENTREPRENEURS GROUP STUDENT ASSOCIATION

detailed_info.club_name: UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO 021 ENTREPRENEURS GROUP STUDENT ASSOCIATION
detailed_info.description: The purpose, objectives, mission and/or mandate of the organization is to 1) establish traditional Chinese culture creation and art platform for students at the University of Toronto. 2) provide UofT students across three campuses with cutting-edge information from venture capital firms, investment institutions, startups, and international trade companies and 3) help students expand their networks with UofT alumni.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Accessibility Awareness Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Accessibility Awareness Club
detailed_info.description: U-TAAC : The voice of students with disabilities since 2021. We host discussions about disability issues in an educational and safe environment for students to share experiences and form connections with the disability community. We facilitate conversations of accessibility between the student body and various branches of Student Life and the University, and offer a disability perspective on several projects. An accessibility club that fosters monthly discussion about disability issues and aims to spread awareness. Our members are students who are both non-registered and registered with Accessibility Services. There are many disability-related clubs and councils out there. But each of them tends to focus on one disability and does not provide students with the chance to form a community, share personal experiences, or a space to educate those who do not have a disability. We aim to fix that by opening our club to more than one type of disability, so that students, with or without disabilities, can express their own experiences, hear from others’ experiences, and learn.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Actuarial Science Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Actuarial Science Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Actuarial Science Club is a student-run organization focused on providing a positive experience for those in the Actuarial Science program. Be it through diverse social events, informational seminars, or workshops, the club strives to prepare Actuarial Science students to perform well in the program and in the industry.

The University of Toronto Aerospace Team (UTAT) is the University of Toronto’s largest student design team, with around 200 active undergraduate and graduate members across all disciplines and backgrounds. The team’s mission is to foster leaders and innovators in aerospace engineering through ambitious design projects, in a challenging and supportive environment, while making a positive impact through technology innovation, policy advocacy, and community outreach. With a mission of working at the cutting edge of aerospace technology, UTAT has developed unique and creative design projects which provide excellent member experience and unparalleled visibility for the university in aerospace.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Allegro Student Choir

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Allegro Student Choir
detailed_info.description: Hello and welcome to the Student Organization Portal (SOP) website of the University of Toronto Allegro Choir! We are a student-led choir that specializes in singing Mandarin and English songs, bringing together different cultures through the universal language of music. Music is an essential part of any culture, reflecting and shaping societal values and emotions. From the enchanting melodies of traditional Beijing operas to the heartwarming strains of native Taiwanese folk songs, and from the passionate expressions of English Romanticism to the soulful tunes of American country rock, music has the power to connect us all. In today’s rapidly evolving world, where technology often reduces face-to-face interaction, Allegro Choir strives to revive this crucial form of communication. By performing songs that represent Chinese and other cultures, we hope to engage with and celebrate the diverse communities that make up our global society. Since our humble beginnings as a student-led club in 2007, Allegro Choir has grown into a semi-professional ensemble, delighting audiences with our captivating performances. This school year, we will continue our weekly rehearsals and plan to perform at numerous events, culminating in our highly anticipated annual year-end concert. The Allegro Choir is not only about making music; it’s also a supportive and inclusive environment where music enthusiasts can learn new skills, forge life-long friendships, and create cherished memories. We invite all U of T students with a passion for singing and an interest in learning Chinese to join our musical family. Stay tuned to this website and our social media platforms for updates on our performances, behind-the-scenes glimpses, and more exciting news about the University of Toronto Allegro Choir! Happy singing!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Alternative Investment Club (UTAIC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Alternative Investment Club (UTAIC)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Alternative Investment Club (UTAIC) is for eager University of Toronto students that are looking to deepen their understanding of the alternative investment space. We provide experiential education through the utilization of case-based learning, trading competitions, and guest speaker events. Some specific sectors within alternatives that we cover include commodities, private equity, hedge funds, and real estate.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Amateur Radio Society (UTARS)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Amateur Radio Society (UTARS)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Amateur Radio Society (UTARS), first established before WWII, aims to develop its members’ technical and professional skills through the art and science of amateur radio. UTARS focuses on antenna design, radio construction, and digital radio, in order to make contacts with radio amateurs in technically challenging ways, and participate in amateur radio contests; and in the process, strives to educate its members about amateur radio, including potentially assisting them in acquiring their Amateur Radio Operator Certificate.

The University of Toronto Anatomy Club (UTA) is a student-run club that aims to provide a fun learning environment for all members interested in the study of anatomy! We welcome undergraduate students of all knowledge levels and years of study. We provide members with anatomy-oriented events including training sessions and case study workshops, as well as relevant networking/mentorship opportunities with upper year students and faculty members.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Anime, Comic & Games (UTACG 多大动漫社)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Anime, Comic & Games (UTACG 多大动漫社)
detailed_info.description: As a non-profit student association, UTACG commits to building a platform for “Otaku” to communicate with each other. Whether you are comic fans, Anime lovers, or video gamers, you are all welcome to join our family. The main social platform we use is Wechat and Discord. During this year with the pandemic, we will try conducting activities online for both new students to UofT and old students so that studying remotely won’t affect their year at UofT.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Archery Student Team

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Archery Student Team
detailed_info.description: Welcome to the UofT Archery Team student portal page! We’re an extra-curricular sports team at UofT that’s here to make archery more accessible and fun! Whether you’ve competed professionally, or never held a bow before, everyone is welcome to join. We created this team with the goal of giving archery-enthusiasts a place to practice, learn, and have fun! We host general meetings for students of all skill levels to try out archery, while receiving help and instruction from experienced archers. Members also have the opportunity to tryout and compete intramurally to become team members, holding competitive roles and participating in cross-campus and inter-university tournaments. We hope to build a strong community of passionate archers, all working together to improve and practice the sport that they love!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Asian Student Alliance (UofT Asian Student Alliance)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Asian Student Alliance (UofT Asian Student Alliance)
detailed_info.description: An inclusivity coalition that connects Asian students, faculty, staff, and Allies at U of T!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Autism Alliance Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Autism Alliance Student Association
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Autism Alliance is a student-run organization that serves to support and advocate for autistic persons through fundraising activities, hosting events for autistic individuals, and volunteering with Autism Ontario. Events include holiday parties and arts & crafts nights, which serve as social learning opportunities for autistic persons. Dedicated student volunteers provide participants with opportunities to express themselves in a safe, non-judgmental environment. Advocacy activities include bake sale fundraisers and educational seminars led by professors and graduate students researching autism.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Autonomous Drone Racing Student Team (UTADR)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Autonomous Drone Racing Student Team (UTADR)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Autonomous Drone Racing Team (UTADR) is a passionate group of roboticists, drone enthusiasts, consisting both graduate and undergraduate engineering students. Our mission is to innovate and lead in the world of autonomous drone racing using cutting-edge AI technologies. We focus on developing first-person-view (FPV) drones equipped with onboard sensors and computers, designed to autonomously navigate complex environments and race through gates in record time. This challenge demands the integration of advanced AI-driven perception, localization, planning, and control algorithms. Our team competes in international autonomous drone racing competitions and contributes to the scientific community by publishing research papers in top-tier journals and conferences. UTADR operates at the Flight System & Control Lab (FSC) and the Learning Systems and Robotics Lab (LSY), the University of Toronto Institute of Aerospace Studies (UTIAS) MarsDome, Myhal Centre for Engineering Innovation and Entrepreneurship, using facilities such as the motion capture system, 3D printers, and GPU clusters. We are committed to fostering a community of students with a shared interest in autonomous drones. By joining UTADR, you’ll engage in hands-on projects, collaborate with experts in the field, and help push the boundaries of AI and drone technology. Whether you’re new to drone racing or an experienced enthusiast, we welcome you to be a part of this exciting journey.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Autonomous Scale Racing Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Autonomous Scale Racing Club
detailed_info.description: With an aim to learn how humans learn to drive and develop better learning based algorithms, and bringing more fun to students and faculties, we bring the adrenaline of RC car racing to UofT, hosting practice runs/races monthly/bi-monthly. At the other times, we work on autonomous driving projects using cutting edge learning based perception methods(such as NERF-SLAM or Gaussian-Splatting-SLAM), and state of the art models for control (such as the Dreamer v3 algorithm), evaluating these on our vision and IMU based RC race car, aiming to be able to compete with professional human competitors. Having research experience/relevant course works on robot perception/state estimation/neural networks and deep learning can be very helpful. Please feel free to join if you’re just looking for a new hobby or being involved in a super cool side project.

Welcome to the University of Toronto Aviation Club! We are a dynamic community of students united by a shared passion for aviation. Our club provides a platform for aspiring pilots, aviation enthusiasts, and aerospace professionals to come together, learn, and explore the fascinating world of aviation.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Biomedical Engineering Design Team

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Biomedical Engineering Design Team
detailed_info.description: UT BIOME is UofT’s only undergraduate biomedical engineering design team. We are based on three core values: developing and implementing innovative solutions, facilitating student exposure and connections to the BME community, and fostering leadership development and teamwork skills. Our projects focus on the research and design, prototyping, and testing phases of product development. We provide a hands-on environment for undergraduate students to learn and apply their knowledge at the intersection of medicine and engineering. Overall, UT BIOME is a great way to get involved in the design process and be informed about the forefront of innovation in the biomedical industry.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Blue Sky Solar Racing

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Blue Sky Solar Racing
detailed_info.description: One of the largest student-run project at the University of Toronto, Blue Sky Solar Racing continues to attract some 100 undergraduate and graduate student volunteers. Blue Sky Solar Racing members hail from a wide variety of disciplines within the university such as Engineering, Computer Science, Chemistry, English, Political Science, and Philosophy. Our members are committed to applying their classroom knowledge, and demonstrating that students of University of Toronto rank among the best in the world.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Buddha’s Light Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Buddha’s Light Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Buddha’s Light Club seeks to provide U of T students with the opportunity to meet regularly in a supportive group setting to practice meditation, discuss Humanistic Buddhism, and develop friendships. There is a profound need for all of us to maintain a balance between the mind and the body. We believe we can help all Chinese students in the following ways: • Deal with stress and other negative states of mind in a productive manner. • Learn about our negative states of mind through the lens of Buddhist teachings and practices. • Foster compassion, loving joy, and equanimity in our daily lives.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Business Students’ Association (UTBSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Business Students’ Association (UTBSA)
detailed_info.description: Originally founded in 2013, the University of Toronto Students’ Business Students’ Association (UTBSA) is a student-led club focused on bringing students of all faculties together to explore the vast opportunities and industries within the business world. Aiming to bridge the gap between academia and business world in an accessible, interactive manner, UTBSA holds both panel and interactive workshop events as well as large scale conferences and case competitions throughout the year, catered towards students of all backgrounds, interested in business.

University of Toronto Calisthenics Club (UTCC) is a space for all those interested in calisthenics and bodyweight fitness to train, chat, and share resources and experiences related to calisthenics. We will be hosting regular meetup training sessions as well as friendly informal competitions once a term.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Cantonese Debate Club (UTCDC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Cantonese Debate Club (UTCDC)
detailed_info.description: The purpose of UTCDC is to provide students with a platform to express different opinions on primary issues in the world. We aim to raise students’ consciousness and generate critical thinking through participating in debates and developing students’ communication and presentation skills. UTCDC will provide regular workshops, training, and competitions to students throughout the school year. Students can understand various forms of arguments and learn how to support a stance in a debate by using multiple resources. By actively participating in our activities and competitions, students will also have great opportunities to improve their public speaking skills. In the previous year, we have been collaborating with HKETO, Canadian Hong Kong Alliance (Toronto), UTHKPASS, and UTSC TSCPA on several debate competitions, allowing students to share their views and make connections with the judges and professionals.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Cast Iron Cooking Club (UofT CICC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Cast Iron Cooking Club (UofT CICC)
detailed_info.description: Hello there! Interested in cooking with the most beautiful cookware of all time? Join the UofT Cast Iron Cooking Club (UofT CICC) where you will learn everything about cast iron cookware! We will teach you everything from how to care for it (seasoning, washing, restoring, storage) and to learning how to cook with it! Cast iron skillets are a fantastic cookware that will last basically your entire life with the right care, and can even be restored if rusted. They are also THE optimal cookware for cooking meats like steak, pork chops, and ground beef. It can even be used to bake foods like paratha and cornbread, or make some bomb kimchi fried rice. You can use it for basically anything. At Uoft CICC, you will learn all about awesome recipes you can make in a simple cast iron skillet that will be sent out in newsletters, can join workshops to learn how to season your cast iron, tips for general cooking, and much more! By the end of the year you will know how to cook the most juiciest, flamboyant, mind-blowing steak that will blow your friends’ minds. We can also accommodate for people of any dietary needs, just let us know when you sign up with us and we will adjust what recipes we send out! Whether you own a cast iron, are interested in getting one, or simply want to join for the ride, you are highly encouraged to join! We only want to spread the awesomeness of cast iron cooking.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Catholic Community of Students (UTCCC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Catholic Community of Students (UTCCC)
detailed_info.description: Established in 2001, we are a community of enthusiastic and committed Chinese Catholic students in the Greater Toronto Area who strive to live out our faith together amidst our busy university lives. UTCCC has regular meetings online and at the Newman Centre at the University of Toronto, St. George campus. Through prayer, discussion, and fellowship we look more closely at our lives and our faith. Other UTCCC events include summer activities, retreats, joint university gatherings, and volunteering.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Finance and Economics Association (UTCFEA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Finance and Economics Association (UTCFEA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Chinese Finance and Economics Association (UTCFEA) is dedicated to advancing academic and professional development in the fields of finance and economics focused on the Chinese market. Finance and economics are central to national development and social stability, encompassing the production, distribution, and consumption of resources. Finance, a key component of the economic system, ensures the proper flow and allocation of funds, fostering business growth and innovation. Although the University of Toronto ranks highly in global economic and business disciplines, its students have relatively weak networks in China’s finance and economics sectors. UTCFEA aims to build a broad and tight-knit network of finance and economic talent, providing career and academic opportunities to bridge this gap. The association embraces 'merchant guild' culture and collaborates with University of Toronto alumni to offer experience sharing and career guidance. We are committed to creating a sustainable community that cultivates future leaders and innovators. UTCFEA values the dignity of labor and the spirit of innovation, opposes malicious competition, and recruits new members through invitation and recommendation. We welcome students of all cultural backgrounds to join our group and collectively explore and focus on the Chinese financial market!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Future Researchers Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Future Researchers Student Association
detailed_info.description: The purpose, objectives, mission and/or mandate of the organization is to help students familiarize themselves with research opportunities at U of T. We provide a platform for connections, enabling students to gain insights directly from professionals from diverse research backgrounds.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Hip-Hop Club (UTCHC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Hip-Hop Club (UTCHC)
detailed_info.description: The purpose of our Chinese Hip-Hop Club is to bring together enthusiasts of Chinese hip-hop culture and foster a vibrant community through dynamic livehouse events. We aim to celebrate and elevate Chinese hip-hop by providing a platform for artists and fans to connect, share their passion, and experience the genre’s unique blend of rhythm, poetry, and cultural expression.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Music Club (UTCMC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Music Club (UTCMC)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Chinese Music Club (UTCMC) is currently the most senior Chinese music organization in the Toronto area. Established in 2012, it has organized various large-scale events such as the Toronto K King Contest, Freshmen Live House, and the Toronto regional competition for 'The Voice of China.' Centred around its singer and musician groups, the club provides professional vocal training and production support for students passionate about music, including opportunities to perform on stage. The club comprises nine administrative departments responsible for event operations, promotion, and internal management. Whether you’re eager to be in the spotlight or enthusiastic about behind-the-scenes work, UTCMC welcomes everyone to join.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Politics Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Politics Club
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Chinese Politics Club, in short UTCPC is an academic organization devoted to promoting discussions, debates, and studies on the academic subjects of Chinese politics, international politics, and Canada-China bilateral relationship. We, UTCPC, organize our academic dialogue in form of a roundtable discussion, both in English and in Chinese. Events such as debates and seminars will also be held at least once in a quarter of a year. UTCPC uphold the virtue of academic rigorousness, all participants, and members will have the rights to share their opinion and critique other opinions. Our executive committee is obligated to oversee the discussions and debates be carried out in accordance with University of Toronto’s academic tradition.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Chinese Student Volunteer Association (UTCSVA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Chinese Student Volunteer Association (UTCSVA)
detailed_info.description: UTCVA (University of Toronto Chinese Volunteer Association) is a U of T recognized campus group initiated by U of T Chinese students. UTCVA pays close attention to the economic and education conditions in some of the less developed regions in rural China. Through our efforts, we hope to bridge these regions with information and resources from other parts of the world, to attract investment from within and outside of china, as well as to enhance the overall education and economic conditions of those regions.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Choose Humanity Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Choose Humanity Club
detailed_info.description: The U of T Choose Humanity Club aims to create a safe and welcoming environment to discuss issues of suppression in modern-day China. We screen award-winning documentaries free of charge and invite distinguished panelists in academia and human rights to engage in Q&A sessions with the audience. We value freedom of thought, open discussion and respectful exchanges of perspectives and ideology.

The University of Toronto Climbing Club (UTCC) aims to get UofT students climbing! Whether you’ve never stepped foot in a climbing gym or you flash V7’s, interested in bouldering, sport climbing, rope climbing or even ice climbing, you’re more than welcome to come to our many events! Take the opportunity to stay fit and socialize with other students at the same time, all the while participating in a fun and safe environment while taking a break from school.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Coders Student Group

detailed_info.description: UofT Coders is a group devoted to helping academics learn computer programming skills for use in their research, as well as teaching best practices in scientific computing, promoting open science and reproducible research practices, and promoting collaboration and resource-sharing among graduate students at the University of Toronto. Through co-working and skill-sharing sessions, as well as more structured lectures on various topics in computing, U of T Coders aims to improve the coding and computing skills of the University of Toronto research community.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Computer Poker Student Research Group

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Computer Poker Student Research Group
detailed_info.description: Since its formation, the University of Toronto Computer Poker Student Research Group has been a forum for both formal and informal discourse in the field of computer poker within the University of Toronto community. Most members in the group are students from the University of Toronto, but we maintain good relations with groups of similar interest from other universities. The group carries out research and/or develops open-source tools to further the world’s poker community often under the guidance of various University of Toronto Professors.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Concrete Toboggan Student Design Team

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Concrete Toboggan Student Design Team
detailed_info.description: Every year our team of dedicated students works to design, build and safely race a concrete toboggan at the Great Northern Concrete Toboggan Race. The toboggan is designed and built entirely by students, which not only provides a hands-on learning environment, but gives us an opportunity to proudly showcase the university at the largest national engineering design competition. As spirit is also judged in our competition, we challenge our creative side by developing a theme, making costumes, and participating in spirit challenges. Concrete Toboggan provides lots of opportunities for young interested engineers to gain all kinds of practical experience. Team members put their design knowledge to the test on real problems, and then participate in the construction, painting, building, sewing and more. The executive positions help to hone many valuable skills such as engineering design, budgeting, organization, scheduling, and giving formal presentations. On top of all this, it’s a great opportunity to meet similar minded students not just within your school but from schools all across the country.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Cooking & Food Club (UCFC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Cooking & Food Club (UCFC)
detailed_info.description: The purpose, objectives, mission and/or mandate of the organization is to educate our peers on cooking while in university through hosting potlucks and providing simple recipes to make cooking less overwhelming. We will have twice-monthly meetings with a theme centering around different cultures and/or countries. Our main objective is to cultivate an environment where cooking is less daunting and welcoming to college students. As well, creating social environments where students can eat new meals with new people.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Cultural Cooking Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Cultural Cooking Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Cultural Cooking Club (UofT Cultural Cooking Club) was founded to bring together chefs, bakers, and food enthusiasts (those who LOVE food but don’t want to make it!) across UofT who have a passion for the art of cooking. We hope to develop a diverse and vibrant community of chefs at all levels of cooking expertise, emphasizing the variety of unique tastes belonging to cuisines across the globe. Come join us as we embark on our journey to explore the secrets cooking has to offer! Each month, events such as online recipes, cooking tutorials, video cooking contests (Cook or Be Cooked!), and trips to cooking festivals located in the heart of Toronto are made to highlight dishes of a select culture. Cook or Be Cooked! is a seasonal cooking contest where we invite people to sharpen their knives, put on their chef hats, and heat up their pans to create a fun video letting their cooking and editing talents run wild. A dish for a select culture is chosen and short videos demonstrating the cooking process from groceries to final product and everything in between are displayed for all members (food critics) to see! The best videos are picked by you and their creators will win awesome prizes! Want some more sauce? Our Discord server allows you to chat with other members, post your own recipes/dishes, and stay in the pot with club events.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Cybersecurity Student Association (CSSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Cybersecurity Student Association (CSSA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Cybersecurity Student Association is a student-run association that aims to develop and promote cybersecurity awareness by bringing students of similar interests together and providing them with cybersecurity resources and events to advance their knowledge in the field.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Digital Currency Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Digital Currency Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Crypto Club is a student run club dedicated to forming a network of those interested in cryptocurrencies (crypto) and blockchain technology. The group hopes to form a community of like-minded individuals looking for neutral, unbiased information pertaining to crypto including: what cryptocurrencies are, their legality and regulation, the underlying technology, and their broader influence on mainstream financial markets and geopolitics.

The mission of the University of Toronto Economics Club is to educate and expand the views of students by introducing them to real-world economic policies and relating them to various concepts learned in class. We hope that this will enrich students’ understanding of economics as a field of study and allow them to apply this knowledge to their careers. Finally, we would like to provide students an opportunity to network and develop their public speaking and critical thinking skills.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Educational Design Student Association (UTEDSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Educational Design Student Association (UTEDSA)
detailed_info.description: Discover the future of education with Instructional Design and Technology at UofT! Our group is for those who are passionate about creating impactful learning experiences through thoughtful design and innovative technology. Dedicated to exploring the dynamic and evolving field of educational design and technology, we provide a collaborative environment for exploring the latest trends and practices in instructional design.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Effective Altruism (Student Chapter)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Effective Altruism (Student Chapter)
detailed_info.description: Given our limited resources, how can we do the most good? University of Toronto Effective Altruism is a new chapter of Effective Altruism, a global movement dedicated to answering that question and acting on our answers. UTEA aims to help students learn about how they can maximize their positive impact through their careers, projects, and donations.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Electronic Music Community (UTEMC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Electronic Music Community (UTEMC)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Electronic Music Community (UTEMC) aims to establish a group of like-minded individuals with an interest in electronic music and DJ events. Through UTEMC, activities and gatherings such as DJ workshops, electronic music production sessions, and DJ events are organised regularly to promote the electronic music culture within U of T. Our vision is to ensure that there is a place for enthusiasts to congregate and discuss upcoming events, new music or meet new people with similar tastes.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Emergency First Responders Club (UTEFR Club)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Emergency First Responders Club (UTEFR Club)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Emergency First Responders (UTEFR) is a Campus Emergency Response Team in Downtown Toronto. We have a passion for promoting and practicing first aid. Knowing first aid can save lives! Our mission is to instill confidence in first aid treatment, to make first aid training readily available to the University of Toronto student body, and to provide quality pre-hospital first aid treatment on campus. We are a team of volunteer students who are trained as First Responders who provide event medical coverage for major organized events on campus, with some seeing over 30,000 people in attendance. Originally, we were a small group of Standard First Aid and CPR-C certified engineering students, the team has grown into a much larger team including Emergency Medical Responders and paramedics, comprising from students of all disciplines. We also run heavily discounted first aid and first responder courses for UofT students and the greater community. Our instructors are all current working medics and base the course content from practical experience and knowledge gained in the field.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Engineering Finance Student Association (UTEFA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Engineering Finance Student Association (UTEFA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Engineering Finance Student Association (UTEFA) is an educational organization that aims to provide students with an exposure to the finance industry. Our mission is to provide an opportunity for students to study and understand various sectors of the Capital Markets through engaging in investing, research, and analysis activities. Core activities of our club include performing analysis on equities, stock pitches, and weekly news updates on hot topics within global Capital Markets. Our alumni have gone on to joining leading firms and financial institutions, including Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, CIBC, and CPP Investments.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Engineering Iron Dragons Dragon Boat Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Engineering Iron Dragons Dragon Boat Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Engineering Iron Dragons is a co-ed dragon boat club, originating and representing the Faculty of Applied Science and Engineering. We provide students with a means to learn and compete in the sport of dragon boat, with recreational and competitive crews. Throughout the year, members will train in the gym and on the water in preparation for the summer racing season between May and August. In previous years, we’ve consistently competed as one of the fastest Eastern Canada U24 mixed, open and women’s teams. This past summer, we competed on the world stage at the Club Crew World Championships in Ravenna, Italy against the best teams in the world. Join us next year for another exciting competitive race season and for a chance to qualify for the next World Championships in Taiwan! We welcome students of all disciplines and experience to join the Iron Dragons family, whether it is to stay fit, try a new sport, or make friends!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Engineering Students Consulting Association (UTESCA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Engineering Students Consulting Association (UTESCA)
detailed_info.description: The goal of University of Toronto Engineering Students Consulting Association is to encourage and foster student interest in the practice and professions of engineering and management consulting. The organization’s focus is to organize student teams that tackle real world problems for clients in the local community through engineering ideas and principles. We offer two types of engagements: – Client Projects Students are recruited in teams to serve as engineering consultants on projects from local organizational clients. They are also matched with industry advisors to guide them through various checkpoints in their project. These engagements conclude with a final presentation and the submission of all final deliverables requested by the client. – Professional Development Events UTESCA hosts several types of professional development events with consulting firms and firm representatives in both engineering and management consulting. These events range from career exploration opportunities like panel discussions to technical skill building workshops to professional development opportunities like case competitions to networking mixers facilitating students’ recruitment in engineering and management consulting.

UTES is a non-profit student group that is the hub for all Esports and gaming communities & activities at the University of Toronto. We aim to unite students by a common love of gaming through community events & discussions on and offline. We encourage you to come out and meet new people!

The University of Toronto Fanfiction Club all about providing a place for the organization of fanfiction readers and writers. In the contemporary era, there are a whole lot of people who read and write fanfiction, and UTFFC wants to provide a safe space for them to meet, free of judgement. No matter the communities, no matter the genre, and no matter the level of one’s writing (if they write at all), all of those with an interest in fanfiction are welcome. The club is about sharing, critiquing, and discussing works of fanfiction, as well as the art as a whole, with relevant events and activities to always keep things fun. The perfect place to find people with like minded interests in fanfiction, and to improve your own fanfiction if you so choose. What’s for certain is no matter why you might join, you’ll be in for a good time!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Fighting Game Community (UofT FGC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Fighting Game Community (UofT FGC)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto’s hub for fighting games! We run tournaments and events for Street Fighter, Guilty Gear, Tekken, and many more. UofT FGC is a place for all types of players, whether you’re a beginner or a fighting game veteran.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Fintech Student Association (UTFTA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Fintech Student Association (UTFTA)
detailed_info.description: Welcome to the forefront of financial innovation, where tradition meets technology and academia meets industry. We are thrilled to present the University of Toronto Fintech Club – a dynamic community where students passionate about finance, technology, and their intersection come together to explore, learn, and shape the future of financial technology.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Flash Photography Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Flash Photography Club
detailed_info.description: The club welcomes photographers of all levels, offering a supportive environment to learn and grow. Members can participate in various activities, access resources, and share their work in a diverse gallery. The club emphasizes creativity, technical skill improvement, and community engagement. The UofT Flash Photography Club aims to foster a community of photography enthusiasts, providing opportunities for members to develop their skills through workshops, hands-on experiences, and guest lectures.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Flutter Devs Students’ Organization (UOFTFDSO)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Flutter Devs Students’ Organization (UOFTFDSO)
detailed_info.description: Mobile App Development has become the easiest it has ever been, thanks to Google’s recent developing tool FLUTTER! At Flutter Devs Organization, we maintain a curious and encouraging environment to learn app development with Flutter and also work together on several app projects that you can show off to your buddies or family! From focusing on app design that will lead to us creating beautiful and appealing apps for the users, to providing our apps functionality, this organization works toward a well-rounded experience in the app development journey.

This is a community of football (soccer) fans and enthusiasts where we organize a variety of football related games and events. We will gather in social outings to watch significant football games, ranging from The Premier League, LaLiga and The Champions League to international matches. We organize friendly matches and participate in a variety of efootball and fantasy football games. People with any range of experience and knowledge are welcome.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Game Design and Development Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Game Design and Development Club
detailed_info.description: The Game Design and Development club aims to bring together anyone interested in the design and development of interactive electronic entertainment. We provide a forum where programmers, artists, musicians and writers can join together to discuss and create video games.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Global Brigades Student Chapter

detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Global Brigades (UTGB) is a chapter of Global Brigades, an international non-profit that uniquely implements a holistic model, aligned with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, to meet a community’s health and economic goals. Every year, we coordinate skill-based weeklong summer brigades and currently host different brigade types to Honduras (Medical, Public Health, Engineering, and Business). Each of these programs fit together to strengthen the health, WASH, and economic development goals of our partner communities. Join us today in building a more equitable world!

The U of T Go Club is a platform for everyone to play Go Chess. It is a great opportunity for players to learn from each other and nurture their passion for Go. The Go Club organises weekly meetings that take place on Friday evening at Myhal; feel free to check out our Discord server for more information. Players with any skill level are welcome to participate. Beginner lessons are available for those who want to learn and play Go for the first time. The U of T Go Club features players with a wide range of Go level, from 10k to 9d! It is perfect for those who are more experienced and want to play with others at similar level. In addition, the U of T Go Club organises annual competitions by partnering with the Canadian Go Association, as well as participating in the Collegiate Go League, where players from the Go Club represent U of T and compete against other colleges and universities.

At UofT Golf Club, we take pride in creating a vibrant and inclusive community for golf enthusiasts of all levels at the University of Toronto. Our mission is to foster a supportive environment where members can connect, play, and learn from each other while promoting golf as a positive and engaging activity. With a focus on regular practice sessions, friendly tournaments, educational events, and social gatherings, we strive to enhance the golfing experience for our members and contribute to their personal growth both on and off the golf course. UofT Golf Club welcomes individuals from all backgrounds, including beginners who are new to golf, as well as experienced golfers looking to improve their skills. We aim to create an inclusive and diverse space where all members feel encouraged to participate, engage, and thrive in the sport of golf. Additionally, our club appeals to students interested in socializing, making friends, and fostering a supportive environment both on and off the golf course.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Graduate Students’ Union (UTGSU)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Graduate Students’ Union (UTGSU)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Graduate Students’ Union (UTGSU) represents over 20,000 students studying in over 115 departments. We advocate for increased graduate student representation and act as a voice for students by lobbying national, and provincial issues on your behalf. The UTGSU engages you through community building events and campaigns, organized by the various Committees and Caucuses. We also offer you a variety of services, such as: health and dental insurance, confidential advice, various grants and bursaries, and access to the UTGSU Building including the UTGSU Pub, Grad Loft and Gym.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Health and Smile Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Health and Smile Club
detailed_info.description: To promote health and wellness through education, advocacy, and community engagement, focusing on dental health, nutrition and overall well-being. The mission of UTHS is to provide students with resources, support, and networking opportunities, especially for those interested in achieving a career in dentistry and nutrition. Through fundraising events, information sessions, and social events, UTHS aims to offer students an encouraging and positive experience.

Our purpose is to create a space for University of Toronto students interested in the study of amphibians and reptiles to share their passion and raise awareness for the conservation and protection of these animals.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Hong Kong Public Affairs and Social Service Affairs Student Association (UTHKPASS)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Hong Kong Public Affairs and Social Service Affairs Student Association (UTHKPASS)
detailed_info.description: The Hong Kong Public Affairs and Social Service Society (UTHKPASS), is first of its kind in North America. As a society built upon the identity of Hong Kong, we strived to promote interest in the social, political and economic affairs of Hong Kong. There are five main goals for UTHKPASS: To conduct policy research on Hong Kong policies in order to fabricate innovating ideas on Hong Kong public affairs; To educate the Hong Kong community at the University of Toronto on Hong Kong public affairs that is frequently raised in Hong Kong society; To foster social awareness regarding Hong Kong minorities and marginalized groups to nurture an inclusive approach on the social issues; To reinforce the Hong Kong community on the school campus so as to strengthen the connections amongst Hong Kong students; To facilitate critical civic discourses regarding Hong Kong affairs through various forms of media.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Hong Kong Students Association (UTHKSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Hong Kong Students Association (UTHKSA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Hong Kong Students Association (UTHKSA) is a student group led by a team of committed and motivated students from Hong Kong. Since its establishment in 2000, UTHKSA has expanded itself to become one of the largest and most prominent Chinese student groups at U of T. Numerous exciting events are organized every year to build and strengthen the ties between the club and its members. Some of these events this year (2022-23) include the annual orientation in September, Chinese New Year gathering dinner, and board games night to get to know each other well. Both new and existing members are all welcome to participate in our fun-filled events. Moreover, all active UTHKSA members are entitled to discounts and benefits at many restaurants and shops around the city! To join UTHKSA, students can sign up at our booth in King’s College Circle during Frosh Week.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Indonesian Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Indonesian Student Association
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Indonesian Student Association (UTISA) is a non-profit cultural organization at the University of Toronto St. George campus. We are a close-knit community whose mission is to provide Indonesian students with a safe and supportive community away from home. We also strive to share Indonesia’s cultural heritage with the UofT community and promote Indonesia’s diverse culture on a global stage.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Ismaili Students Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Ismaili Students Association
detailed_info.description: The UTSG Ismaili Students Association (UTSGISA) is a collective space for all Ismaili Muslims studying at the University of Toronto’s St George and Mississauga campuses. We aim to support Ismaili students with opportunities for regular prayer and faith engagement, to help them explore and engage with their spirituality, and develop a strong sense of community whilst at the University, and as part of our alumni network after graduation. Our community events, which are also open to non-Ismailis, are oriented around dance, sport, cultural celebration, academic and professional development, debate and discussion, personal and mental wellbeing, with many more as our community and society grows.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Japan Network of Students

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Japan Network of Students
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Japan Network aims to make a stimulating environment that will encourage ambitious U of T associated individuals to discover and stimulate each other in the form of new ideas, future paths, passions and interests. It also will aim to build “a strong interlinking network of U of T students”. Our ultimate goal is to spread awareness of University of Toronto in Japan and become the most exceptional network of bilingual students in North America.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Japan Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Japan Student Association
detailed_info.description: The purpose of UTJA is to promote and facilitate the exchange of Japanese culture and language between students on and off campus. Events and activities will allow students to experience certain aspects of Japanese culture, while Japanese language-related events will cater to students who are interested in the Japanese language. This club will also serve as a platform for other Japanese students to connect with each other.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Korean Commerce Community Club (UTKCC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Korean Commerce Community Club (UTKCC)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Korean Commerce Community, shortened as UTKCC is the highly motivated student organization devoted to enhancing the networking and information sharing among Korean students and alumni in the Commerce and Economics fields at the University of Toronto. Focused on providing individualized support, UTKCC assists students in their academic endeavors, extracurricular activities, and overall university experience. Drawing upon the expertise and connections of our upper-year students and accomplished alumni, we offer a range of opportunities designed to meet the unique needs of our members. Each year, we organize a series of events that focus on career development and networking, all enhanced by our robust KCC Alumni Network. Our goal is to empower our students to excel in both their academic and professional journeys, setting them up for long-term success.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Korean Engineering Students’ Association (UTKESA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Korean Engineering Students’ Association (UTKESA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Korean Students’ Association (UTKESA) for Engineering aims to build a strong network among Koreans residing in Toronto and across Canada who are connected to the engineering field. Through various events and academic support, we strive to foster connections and provide assistance within the Korean community. We are to create a supportive Korean community for UofT engineering students, offering ample support for their academic pursuits and future careers.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Law and History Club (UTLHC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Law and History Club (UTLHC)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto’s Law and History Club is dedicated to fostering an inclusive and intellectually stimulating environment where students can explore the intersections of law and history. Our mission is to engage members in meaningful discussions and help them develop a deeper understanding of how historical contexts influence contemporary legal issues. We provide a platform for academic growth, critical thinking, and collaborative learning through various events, lectures, and activities. By bridging the gap between legal studies and historical analysis, we strive to cultivate a community of well-rounded individuals who are prepared to contribute thoughtfully and effectively to the legal profession and society at large. Join us to deepen your knowledge, connect with like-minded peers, and be part of a vibrant intellectual culture at the University of Toronto.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Legends of The Three Kingdoms Student Group

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Legends of The Three Kingdoms Student Group
detailed_info.description: Our club mainly aims to gather some Legends of the Three Kingdoms players to have fun together in our free time. Legends of the Three Kingdoms is a traditional card game based on the history of the Three Kingdoms of China. It can inherit and learn Chinese history and culture while entertaining. Players can use the characters of the Three Kingdoms period during the game and experience the intriguing atmosphere of the Three Kingdoms period immersively through operations, teamwork, etc. At the same time, it can also exercise players’ logical thinking, the abilities of cooperation, and the formation of troops.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Machine Intelligence Student Team (UTMIST)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Machine Intelligence Student Team (UTMIST)
detailed_info.description: UTMIST is a club dedicated to clearing the mist surrounding machine intelligence. Machine intelligence is a field that involves many significant applications such as self-driving cars, facial recognition, and search engines. We are passionate about exploring and applying the fields of machine intelligence to real-world scenarios. We hold project-based workshops and events centered around topics such as machine learning and data science. Our club provides opportunities for members to discuss and pursue research into the latest machine learning techniques and to apply them to emerging applications. Our club is an inclusive community for students coming from all backgrounds of knowledge and experience.

The club strives to represent students who have an interest in the game of Mahjong at the University of Toronto, St. George Campus; to spread appreciation for this ancient game to the modern world of today. We wish to advocate an inclusive and positive learning environment regardless of skill level or experience. We highly encourage our members to actively participate in an environment relevant to the rich history and traditions of Mahjong. Due to the nature of this game, the club has a zero-tolerance policy on gambling in all activities associated.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Mental Health Student Association (UofTMHA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Mental Health Student Association (UofTMHA)
detailed_info.description: The purpose of this not-for-profit student-run association is to break the stigma surrounding mental health and empower students through their mental health journeys while also practicing diversity, equity & inclusion. We strive to educate and promote healthy coping mechanisms among students struggling with their mental health and aim to make mental health resources a lot more accessible to students. We aim to do this by hosting events, seminars, workshops, fundraisers, and other initiatives throughout the year to raise awareness and educate UofT students as well as members of the community on various mental health themes. In our approach, we aim to increase representations of various mental health topics and amplify voices of underrepresented groups within the university space online and in-person while constantly obtaining ongoing feedback from club members and the UofT community to better cater our initiatives towards their needs.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Mindful Balance Collective

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Mindful Balance Collective
detailed_info.description: Our mission is to foster a supportive community where students can explore and practice mindfulness as a tool for achieving balance in their academic, personal, and social lives. We aim to integrate mindfulness into daily routines to enhance well-being and resilience. Through workshops, discussions, and events, we aim to help students to develop self-awareness, manage stress, and build meaningful connections. By encouraging a balance lifestyle, we hope to support students in succeeding in various aspects of their lives and contributing positively to the university community.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Mock Trial Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Mock Trial Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Mock Trial Club is the full realization of almost a decade of mock trial competition at UofT and the University of Toronto Pre-Law Students’ Association (UTPLSA). Host to Canada’s first, and most dominant, Canadian and American (AMTA) Mock Trial teams, including the first Canadian team to advance to the AMTA National Championship, the UofT Mock Trial Club is home to the most competitive mock trial programs in Canada. With dozens of competition wins, awards at the highest levels, and recognition for not just our competitive prowess but also civility, UofT Mock Trial is the perfect place to learn Mock Trial and compete with the best. Whether you’ve done mock trial before, or are totally new to the activity, we welcome everyone to come learn from the best competitors in Canada.

This club aims to provide access for University of Toronto students who are interested in motorcycles to learn about motorcycles. In the club, we will teach students how to ride motorcycles, how to maintain motorcycles and safe riding training. For students who are familiar with motorcycles, we provide a communication platform for motorcycle fans within the University of Toronto. At the same time, we will organize students with driving licenses and motorcycles to participate in group riding activities. We are also very interested in motorcycle racing. Our goal is to establish a closed-track motorcycle racing competition for higher education students in North America within 4 years from the founding of the club. We will also carry out motorcycle modification competitions every year to encourage students to try to design their own style of motorcycle.

This student group is dedicated to the practice and study of Atarashii Naginata (Modern Naginata) and its growth in North America. The group helps to foster the development of Naginata practitioners and athletes within the university and collegiate communities of Canada by providing the opportunity to do and study modern Naginata within a university club context. Classical Naginata is also studied when an appropriate teacher (sensei) is present.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Open Source Students (UTOSS)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Open Source Students (UTOSS)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Open-Source Society (UTOSS) is a design team that focuses on developing and contributing to existing open-source hardware and software projects. Our hardware team aims to work with FPGAs, develop their own digital system architectures, and contribute to major HDL repositories. Our software team contributes to industry-standard tools like Knative, Kubernetes, and possibly Linux or PyTorch in the future. We hold both long and short-term projects for students to develop both software and hardware skills in the open-source mindset and using open-source tools. Anyone looking to join and learn about hardware, software, or the open source environment is welcome!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Outing Club (UTOC) Student Chapter

detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Outing Club (UTOC) was established in 1957. The UTOC Student Chapter, formally established in 2024, is composed of students, faculty and staff who are interested in a variety of outdoor activities including but not limited to canoeing, camping and hiking. Club members are encouraged to organize outdoor focused trips of all manner. UTOC also owns a cabin near Metcalfe Rock at the Niagara Escarpment where members have access throughout the year.

Pilates is an exercise system that trains the whole body for strength and flexibility. It helps improve posture and helps reduce tension and strain in the body. Pilates is versatile, it is for everyone, and you can do it anywhere! The student group UofpilaTes aims to give students an opportunity to: -Learn more about Pilates -Receive information about pilates studios in Toronto -Sign up for free beginner classes given by a Uoft student who is a certified Pilates instructor. It is a low commitment club that is meant to be welcoming, inclusive and fun!

Welcome to the University of Toronto Pokémon Club (UTPC), where Trainers from all corners of the Pokémon world come together! Our club features three exciting divisions: Pokémon GO, Pokémon Card Trading, and Pokémon Core Games. Whether you’re a dedicated Trainer in one of these games or just a fan of the Pokémon universe, there’s a place for you here. Even if you’re not active in the games, you can still join our vibrant community to connect with passionate Trainers, share your love for Pokémon, and participate in a variety of events and activities.

Since its formation, the University of Toronto Poker Club has been at the forefront of promoting the game of poker, advancing the skills of its members, and connecting the players within the University of Toronto community. The club runs social events, games, and tournaments campus-wide. In addition, the club forms coalitions with the individual colleges’ poker clubs, promote their events and aim to establish a sustainable poker community. The club denounces financial gambling and advocates the sporting side of poker.

University of Toronto Policython aims to educate and challenge students interested in Policy and Government, Diplomacy, and related fields by holding an annual Policython. This event combines the educational insight offered by MUNs and the fast-paced, high pressure nature of hackathons to allow students to put their abilities and skills to the test in a fun and fulfilling way. At the end of the event, participants will have created a policy brief to be judged by experts and potentially awarded. Additionally, UTP’s educational mission is to equip students looking into careers related to government and diplomacy with beneficial knowledge and skills on diplomatic tools of government through Policython training. UTP is committed to making U of T an inclusive environment. The policies proposed must be progressive and respective of marginalized populations facing significant obstacles both domestically and internationally. We are also committed to accessibility and will hold these missions central to all club actions moving forward.

The University of Toronto Polo Club is a non-for-profit club dedicated to rendering the sport of polo accessible to all interested U of T undergraduates, with the final goal of sevā (Sanskrit for selfless service). U of T Polo’s duplexity lies in its aim to share the history & rules of the sport, as well as to offer members the chance to experience the sport of polo, view a tournament and/or horseback time if desired. A social and relaxed club, new members can expect camaraderie, regular brunch socials downtown, and social gatherings to amass funds to charities and club operation. Through the sport and entertainment of polo, we hope to provide certain aid to medical, social, and environmental challenges that impact our communities and concern the student body at large. Students from all backgrounds are highly encouraged to participate in the sport, inexperienced and experienced players alike.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Portuguese Student Associations (UTPA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Portuguese Student Associations (UTPA)
detailed_info.description: Our club represents Portuguese and Portuguese-speaking students at the University of Toronto. Every year the University of Toronto Portuguese Association (U.T.P.A.), a group of students who are interested in the Portuguese culture, promote new coming Portuguese and Portuguese-speaking students (and all students) to come to the university to study. Our message is that Lusophone young students can be whoever they would like to become. The UTPA is here to help them on their journey. We show students that university life does not have to be a lonely journey but rather it can be an opportunity to meet new people, to have new opportunities. We get involved in many Outreach programs like Adopt-a-Student Day, our peer mentoring program which allows 1st and 2nd year students to be paired up with upper-year students who are available to guide them through their University journey. We also have a scholarship program every year for new students of Portuguese descent who come to the University to study. Our members are not all necessarily of Portuguese descent – some are Portuguese, most Luso-Canadian and others from other nationalities. Our only requirements to be a member are having an interest in the Portuguese culture, being a dedicated person, and being a team member. It is in the hands of our members to promote our message. Each member has the right to speak out. We have our Social Coordinators that plan events, discuss the details and plan out when, where, and how the event is to happen. Our Secretary stays in contact with other clubs, events, and news, and relays the information to the other group members. The Secretary is also the person who others contact if they want to apply for the scholarship or need specific information about our association. Our Web Designer designs our website, as well as updates it with any news and upcoming events. Our Treasurer is responsible for our financial affairs. He/she controls the expenses versus the profits and is responsible to work out our budgets for our events. The President and Vice-President are the contact people for specific problems or concerns that some may have. They are the people who decide the positions, have the right to decide who is committed and responsible and who is fulfilling their tasks. They are also responsible to get the club’s recognition and any specific campus rights they may require. Above all, all of our members are students themselves, so we have to balance our duties and schedules, which is not an easy task. We are all friends and we enjoy being part of a small but growing group. Many other students are aware of us and get involved during an event, but decide that they do not have the time to attend the meetings of the UTPA. For the members who are part of the UTPA, it is a comfortable and fun environment. It is a chance to make new friends and to plan and develop new contacts. We celebrate every ending UTPA year with a scholarship dinner, our “Primavera Gala” at which we reward our Luso-Canadian scholarship winners who have been admitted to the University of Toronto. They are also featured in our annual magazine, “Origens”, which includes all of our events during that school year and news that may be important for anyone who is interested in joining. This year the UTPA is hoping to have a fantastic year; one that we can make the founders and past members of the UTPA proud of. We will leave the constitution with a few words that one of our past members had expressed towards the UTPA: “In a school that is so big and where it seems that you are outnumbered, where everyone seems to be successful and where many times you feel lost, having a place to belong like the UTPA has made me comfortable and confident. It has made my university years much easier. Thank you UTPA team.” a Luso-Portuguese, previous UTPA member.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Pre-Dental Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Pre-Dental Student Association
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Pre-Dental Association seeks to actively engage and connect students who are interested in the field of dentistry with one another as well as with dentists, researchers, and dental scholars. It will provide students with an opportunity to be familiarized with the various branches of dentistry.
