Non-pre-dental students with various backgrounds who have a keen interest in this field will also have a chance to take part in spreading global dental health awareness.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Pre-Law Students’ Association (UTPLSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Pre-Law Students’ Association (UTPLSA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Pre-Law Students’ Association is a student-administrated, campus-recognized organization committed to providing students with information concerning law school, legal careers, and other related resources. Whether you are unsure about entering the legal field, dead set upon it, or looking for law-related experiences, we invite you to join our community by signing up for membership and taking part in our teams and events.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Pre-Medical Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Pre-Medical Student Association
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Pre-Medical Student Association (UTPMSA) fosters a supportive and informative environment for aspiring medical professionals. Members gain access to the latest information on medical school admissions, including academic requirements, MCAT criteria, application processes, and extracurricular opportunities. UTPMSA’s events feature medical symposiums with representatives from various medical schools, networking sessions with current medical students, and comprehensive information sessions about the pre-med journey. By joining UTPMSA, members can expect to refine their skills, expand their network, and gain valuable insights into the path to becoming a medical professional.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Pre-Pharmacy Student Association (UTPPSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Pre-Pharmacy Student Association (UTPPSA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Pre-Pharmacy Student Association is a student-led group at the University of Toronto St. George Campus that aims to foster a community of enthusiastic students interested in pursuing pharmacy to collaboratively build skills and engage in learning about topics in the field. Through our events, we hope to promote interest in pharmacy, provide accessible information regarding admissions processes, and connect students with professionals in the field and resources for success.

The University of Toronto Psychedelic club exists to support advocacy efforts, foster academic discourse, spark new research projects and build community within the emerging field of psychedelic medicine. As a group, we plan to engage in helping shape the legal and regulatory framework to incorporate harm-reduction principles while ensuring policy aligns with scientific evidence and is poised to provide the greatest benefit to humanity. In addition to advocacy work, journal club and research presentations will enable students to engage with leading research in the fields of neuroscience, psychology, pharmacology, chemistry and psychiatry. Beyond the usual networking that happens at social events, we seek to provide spaces where students can connect on a deeper level and form valuable personal relationships.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Public Speaking Club (UTPS)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Public Speaking Club (UTPS)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Public Speaking Club (UTPS) provides an inclusive and supportive environment for students to improve their oral communication skills. UTPS brings together students from all disciplines and backgrounds to study the art of public speaking and to overcome their fears.

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Quadball Club St George
detailed_info.description: Looking for a new and exciting sport to try out? Look no further than Quadball (formerly Quidditch), a co-ed, newcomer-friendly, full-contact sport that is a mix of handball, dodgeball and rugby. Whether you’re an athlete or a sports beginner, everyone is welcome to learn, practice, and play Quadball. If you want to enjoy a healthy and active lifestyle while making friends, Quadball might just be what you’re looking for. The UofT Quadball Club – The Centaurs – was formed early in 2009 when members of the McGill Quadball team travelled through a blistering cold Canadian winter storm to pass on the skills of the sport to their Toronto siblings. We have been growing ever since, competing against other university and community teams, all while having a wonderful time.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Republic of Movie Believers (UTRMB)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Republic of Movie Believers (UTRMB)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Republic of Movie Believers (UTRMB) is a community for movie and film lovers who are passionate about storytelling and visual arts. Each year, we produce one annual short film, allowing members to participate in every stage of the filmmaking process—from scriptwriting to post-production. In addition, we work on other exciting film and video-related projects throughout the year, providing opportunities to learn, collaborate, and explore creative ideas in a supportive environment. Whether you’re an experienced filmmaker or just starting out, there’s a place for you here!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Research Network Club (UTRN)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Research Network Club (UTRN)
detailed_info.description: Our club motto, “bridging the gap between research inquiry and education for all University of Toronto students,” aims to help students from all backgrounds (STEM and non-STEM) gain research experiences, and allow students to share their experiences in academia. Research paths that students in the club are pursuing include but are not limited to life sciences, physical sciences, social sciences, kinesiology, architecture, and more. UTRN’s events include but are not limited to educational seminar, “how to” sessions,” tailored to students conducting research in any field.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Riichi Mahjong Club (多大雀魂社)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Riichi Mahjong Club (多大雀魂社)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Riichi Mahjong Club aims to provide a social platform for students who holds an interest in the complex and competitive game of Riichi Mahjong. We welcome students to come learn, improve, and make new acquaintances who holds this same interest. We promote and teach the statistically optimized theory of playing Riichi Mahjong, including the use of computational software and artificial intelligence software (eg. Naga) as aids in post-game analysis. We strive to provide a friendly learning environment for players of all skill level. We periodically hold in-person game events and online game events (via Maj-soul and Tenhou) to promote member enjoyment of the amazing and deep game.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Risk Analysis Club (UTRAC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Risk Analysis Club (UTRAC)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Risk Analysis Club aims to allow the student body of the University of Toronto to explore and practice their skills in risk identification, examination, and management. Students will collaboratively work on reports that analyze recent events and the potential risks they could lead to for businesses and organizations. UTRAC will also conduct events that will provide the student body with opportunities to interact with and learn from professionals in the field of Risk Analysis and Management.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Robotics Association (Student Design Team)

detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Robotics Association (UTRA) is an organization composed of U of T alumni, professors and undergraduate students from the Faculties of Applied Science & Engineering and Arts & Science. The Association was formed in the winter of 2002 with the objective to design, build and maintain robots to be used in internationally recognized robotics competitions such as Intelligent Ground Vehicle Competition (IGVC), RoboBrawl, PacBot, and the RoboCup Competition. Students gain valuable experience in activities ranging from the engineering of robots to financial management and most importantly, real-world application of their education. We will be committed to further promoting the educational impact of UTRA by organizing lectures and seminars pertaining to university research and the robotics industry as a whole. We are also committed to the community through high school outreach by promoting the fields of engineering, robotics, and the University as a whole.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Rocket Riders — The Student Transit Forum

detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Rocket Riders is an independent, non-partisan student group which aims to represent the interests of students as they relate to transit policy in Toronto, and serve as a social club for said students. The name derives from the famous Toronto Transit Commission (TTC) slogan, “Ride the Rocket”. The Rocket Riders seek to address the lack of an organization at the University of Toronto’s St. George campus that advocates for student interests in transit issues. The Rocket Riders will serve to hold the University of Toronto Students’ Union, the university administration, and relevant levels of government to account. Aside from advocacy, the Rocket Riders also hold transit-related events and serves as a forum for everything transit at St. George.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Sahaja Yoga Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Sahaja Yoga Club
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Sahaja Yoga Club offers free meditation classes that allow you to connect with your true self. Open to all skills and ages, hope to see you there!

UofT Sailing offers both competitive and recreational sailing opportunities. Our competitive team competes in the Canadian Intercollegiate Sailing Association (CICSA) and the Mid Atlantic Sailing Association (MAISA) in the United States. We train and compete in the fall, with teams attending regattas every weekend and individuals attending at least 2 regattas a season. Our recreational program requires no previous experience and individuals go out on keelboats with 4 or 5 others and a trained instructor. You can sign up for every weekend or attend on a drop in basis. It is a great way to get outdoors and experience a new sport with your friends or meet new people.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Science Nexus Club (UTSN)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Science Nexus Club (UTSN)
detailed_info.description: We’re a passionate group interested in the diverse applications of science in various industry fields. We want to bring unique opportunities to students, through networking events from top industry leaders, ranging from Biotech, to Science Consulting, Pharma, and R&D.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Serbian Students Association (U of T SSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Serbian Students Association (U of T SSA)
detailed_info.description: The Serbian Students Association of the University of Toronto is an independent, non-political organization whose foremost purpose is to promote and portray Serbian culture within the Serbian and University communities.

Given the scarcity of Shogi players in English-speaking regions, we are establishing a Shogi club at the University of Toronto with three bold objectives in mind. Firstly, we plan to organize events to promote Shogi, initially within the university and subsequently throughout the city of Toronto. Secondly, we aim to develop an English-language website catering to novice Shogi players, addressing the current language barrier posed by the availability of resources predominantly in Japanese. Thirdly, we intend to conduct AI research on Shogi, leveraging the computer science knowledge of our members to apply and demonstrate the skills learned in class. Our ultimate goal is to popularize Shogi through various platforms and to advance AI research by utilizing the knowledge and skills acquired at the university, thus bridging the gap between this rich traditional game and the global, English-speaking community.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Ski and Snowboard Club (UTSSC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Ski and Snowboard Club (UTSSC)
detailed_info.description: NA

club_info.name: University of Toronto Smash Ultimate Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Smash Ultimate Club
detailed_info.description: UTSmash was formed to act as a central gathering point for Super Smash Bros. Ultimate (Smash Ultimate) players and enthusiasts at the University of Toronto. UTSmash aims to foster, promote, and expand our Smash Ultimate community. UTSmash holds weekly in-person events to provide players with a space to interact and compete in our diverse community. Stop by if you love Smash and want to have a great time! Most of our communication is done through our Discord server, so be sure to join that!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Spiritual-Adversarial-Pagan Students’ Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Spiritual-Adversarial-Pagan Students’ Association
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Spiritual-Adversarial-Pagan Students’ Association (UTSAP) is a membership organization for U of T students, staff, alumni and faculty who practice paganism, earth-based spiritual traditions, and/or adversarial occult philosophies. UTSAP is non-denominational and inclusive of all self-defined non-organized paths and traditions focused on earth-based spirituality, including folk, polytheistic, nature-based, wiccan, pagan, and ancestral traditions and adversarial philosophies, such as a/theistic Satanism, Luciferianism, and Lilith worship. UTSAP seeks to welcome and reflect the diversity of the University of Toronto community in our membership and through our events. UTSAP also has the mission to engage with and educate the community about the wide array of pagan and folk spiritual traditions and concepts, and to promote inter-faith learning and cooperation. We strive to create a place where students have a community that aids their spiritual journey alongside their academics. Individuals who wish to learn more about paganism, earth-based spirituality and adversarial philosophies are also encouraged to UTSAP membership and/or its events.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Sports Analytics Student Group

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Sports Analytics Student Group
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Sports Analytics Student Group is a group composed of University of Toronto members who have an interest in the field of sports analytics. The group aims to: 1) connect members who share a passion for the field, 2) organize and conduct research in the field, 3) connect members to industry leaders in the field.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Sports and Business Student Association (UTSB)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Sports and Business Student Association (UTSB)
detailed_info.description: Since 2011, the University of Toronto Sports and Business Association (UTSB) has been bringing some of the best sports business conferences to the University of Toronto. Consistently delivering impressive lineups of speakers, UTSB has made it a mantra to bridge the gap between students and the sports industry. Our events host an impressive outreach that includes students, faculty, alumni, and industry professionals from numerous organizations located both within the GTA and across North America. Our flagship event, the Toronto Sports Industry Conference (TSIC), strives to provide top-notch opportunities for in-depth discussions, career development, and shine lights toward the ones who deserve recognition. We are committed to improving North American sports industry development, specifically the uprising Canadian industry.

club_info.name: University of Toronto St George IGNITE! Student Club

detailed_info.description: UTSG IGNITE! is a club focused on providing students with an on-campus student-led group that includes but goes beyond Christian fellowship by also focusing on personal development. Though there are other religious and spiritual groups, this club will focus on how the Christian faith can help us to develop as well-rounded individuals. As students, it is important that a group such as this exists to help students put their faith into real-world practices. Our five pillars ensure that members grow as students, team players, and generally as individuals in every meeting. They help us center each meeting on some form of personal development. The pillars are: (1) discovery of purpose; (2) talent expression; (3) professional and leadership development; (4) productive engagement; and (5) strategic relationships. These pillars represent what students can expect to gain from being a member of the club and are the foundation of every club activity.

club_info.name: University of Toronto St. George Debate Club (UTSGDC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto St. George Debate Club (UTSGDC)
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto St. George Debate club invites members to explore interesting debate topics through participation and observation of debates. UTSGDC aims to improve members’ logical and argumentative skills through fact-based debates. The Club acts as a safe space for members to argue their perspectives using strategy and rationale. UTSGDC members do not work towards competition but rather towards improving personal speaking, debating, and strategic argument sequencing. University of Toronto St. George Debate Club not only focuses on the advancement of debating skills, but largely works to make sure that all members have a memorable and fun experience. The Club offers a myriad of marvellous and accessible events, ranging from ‘question-and-answer’ sessions with high profile lawyers, professors, and speaking coach professionals, various debate sessions, and social opportunities. All are welcome and all are encouraged to join!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student A Cappella Coalition (UTAC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student A Cappella Coalition (UTAC)
detailed_info.description: UTAC is a student-run club that aims to bring together the different a cappella groups at the University of Toronto. Our goal is to provide support for the existence, growth and development of the groups and the a cappella environment at the University of Toronto. We provide opportunities for skill development for all of our members, and promote the presence of University of Toronto’s a cappella groups within and outside of the university’s community!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Anime and Manga Association (UT-SAMA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Anime and Manga Association (UT-SAMA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Student Anime and Manga Association (UT-SAMA) was founded in September 2004. The club was formed with the intention of bringing together people with similar interests in Japanese animated and illustrated media. The Art Studio and Light Music Club subgroups work to promote the creation and discussion of related visual art and music. Through regular meetings, contests, and events, members of UT-SAMA seek to spread awareness and appreciation of this growing form of entertainment throughout the university community.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Association of Chinese Engineers (UTACE)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Association of Chinese Engineers (UTACE)
detailed_info.description: As one of the most iconic and largest Chinese student organizations at the University of Toronto, the Association of Chinese Engineers (UTACE) was founded in 2016 as a result of the merging of two previous clubs with over 40 years of history, the Chinese Engineering Students’ Association (CESA) and the Engineering Chinese Club (ECC). As a non-profit organization, UTACE is dedicated to promoting Chinese culture, enriching student experience in university, and creating connections and a sense of belonging among different generations by offering all kinds of support and services within the Engineering Society and the University of Toronto in general. Over the past few years, UTACE has held a large variety of events throughout the academic year, covering all aspects of student life, including academia, career planning, social skill development, and entertainment, which has received a lot of positive feedback, both from the faculty and the students.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Chapter for Healing on Practice Education (U of T’s H.O.P.E)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Chapter for Healing on Practice Education (U of T’s H.O.P.E)
detailed_info.description: Healing On Practice Education (H.O.P.E.) is dedicated to cultivating compassionate and skilled medical professionals in the Dominican Republic, fostering solidarity, and bridging healthcare gaps for equitable access. The missions are to educate and empower healthcare professionals to serve vulnerable communities, emphasizing humanization and friendly medical practice. U of T’s H.O.P.E will organize trips which will be planned by all participants. The trip will encompass two different settings: first, we will visit communities without access to medical care, providing essential services under the supervision of local doctors to ensure our efforts are impactful and sustainable. Second, participants will have the opportunity to shadow medical professionals in local hospitals, gaining experiences not available in Canada and developing a global health perspective. Additionally, all participants can request specific places to volunteer, such as orphanages, nursing homes, or communities for individuals with disabilities, tailoring the experience to their interests and ensuring a diverse impact. Join us in building a global network of empathetic healers dedicated to making a transformative impact on underserved communities!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Chapter Global Medical Training

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Chapter Global Medical Training
detailed_info.description: Global Medical Training (GMT) is an international humanitarian organization that provides free medical and dental services to rural communities in Central America. GMT organizes an annual trip for this purpose, granting university students interested in healthcare an opportunity to learn from local doctors and pharmacists at a level medical residents experience. The trips serve to teach students how to treat patients despite cultural, language, and educational differences while respecting their autonomy and diversity. We hope students can recognize the detrimental impacts of underserved communities and be inspired to push more initiatives locally and internationally. Independent of the external organization, UofT GMT also develops and funds global crisis response initiatives and serves as a pre-medicine community for incoming students.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Chapter of the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (UT-EERI)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Chapter of the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (UT-EERI)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Student Chapter of the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (UT-EERI) is dedicated to advancing earthquake engineering and nurturing a cohesive community spanning undergraduates, graduates, professors, industry experts, and the broader public. Our mission involves cultivating deep engagement in seismic engineering through diverse Chapter activities. UT-EERI graduate members play a pivotal role by hosting academic and industrial guest lectures, mentoring the Undergraduate Seismic Design Competition (SDC) team, actively participating in the EERI community through volunteering, and advocating for enhanced comprehension of earthquakes’ impact on physical, social, economic, and political environments.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Environmental Resource Network (UTERN)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Environmental Resource Network (UTERN)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto’s Environmental Resource Network (UTERN) is a levy organization that operates as a funding body and networking hub for any person, group or club within the university community interested in sustainability and environmentalism on campus. UTERN membership is open to all students, faculty, staff and alumni from any of the three campuses at the University of Toronto.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Fashion Collective

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Fashion Collective
detailed_info.description: The purpose of .UTFC is to spark confidence in students by introducing them to the world of modeling and fashion. .UTFC provides a modeling space that is gender, body-positive, and inclusive to everyone in the UofT community. We also understand that university is a huge and scary place for students! So this club is meant to provide a platform for small designers, models, artists, and photographers who want to start showcasing their work. .UTFC provides an inclusive space and a friendly environment that allows like-minded people who enjoy fashion to come together to learn about the different fashion subcultures out there, and their progression throughout the years. The club would also love to welcome students who are interested in participating in an annual fashion show to boost their confidence on stage and gain experience. This also provides an opportunity for creatives (designers, photographers, artists) to boast their work.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student Research Initiative

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student Research Initiative
detailed_info.description: The core purpose of the University of Toronto Student Research Initiative is to foster a spirit of innovation and research among undergraduate students across all three University of Toronto campuses. By setting up a competition-based research platform, we are aiming to provide undergraduate students with a unique opportunity to engage in STEM research projects, potentially in collaboration with Master’s and Ph.D students. This will not only enhance their academic and professional skills but also promote interdisciplinary collaboration and networking among students at different stages of their academic journey.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student’s Astronomy and Space Exploration Association (ASX)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student’s Astronomy and Space Exploration Association (ASX)
detailed_info.description: The Astronomy & Space Exploration Association is a non-profit organization run by the University of Toronto space community, in Ontario, Canada. ASX’s purpose is to educate, excite, and inspire students, professionals, and the general public about astronomy and space. Since its inception in 2003, ASX has rapidly grown to over 1500 members, and has organized and hosted 10 or more events per year, attracting hundreds of event attendees each year. ASX’s signature event is the annual Symposium, which has attracted an audience of up to 500 people in a single event. Other events include the “Star Talk” Lecture Series, Panel Discussions, Space Exploration Showcase, and Observing Nights. Topics of discussion have covered various facets of space, such as ‘Mars and Beyond’, ‘The Search for Life’, ‘Cosmology from the Stratosphere’, and ‘Space Business’.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Student’s Consulting Association (UTCA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Student’s Consulting Association (UTCA)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Consulting Association (UTCA) is a diverse organization that provides students from different fields with the opportunity to begin exploring the world of consulting. Through our workshops, case competitions, and other events, students learn to assess real-world problems and solve them through innovative solutions. We also host several events that allow students to network with representatives from some of the top consulting firms, learn more about career paths, develop meaningful relationships, and break into the industry. While our organization continues to evolve over the years, we stand by our consistent goal of providing an accessible way to expand students’ horizons through a platform of exposure and opportunities. Our organization also manages a volunteer Consulting Group (CG) which matches top students with local non-profits and start-ups to solve current business problems.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Students for a Free Iran (UTSFI)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Students for a Free Iran (UTSFI)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Students for a Free Iran (UTSFI) is an independent social organization that seeks to promote diversity and freedom for Iranians and Iranian-Canadians at the University of Toronto. UTSFI seeks to create a safe and inclusive space for the Iranian and Iranian-Canadian academic community to engage with and preserve the Iranian cultural and historical heritage. UTSFI acknowledges the unacceptable history of oppression based on gender, ethnicity, and religion in Iran. UTSFI has been formed to: (1) address this history of oppression, (2) preserve and document it, (3) and provide an open platform to the Iranian community to emerge as a free society from this history. UTSFI is non-partisan and non-religious. While aiming to promote freedom, equality, and liberty for the Iranian community, UTSFI will not advocate the interest of any political and/or religious entity. UTSFI is a non-profit organization. UTSFI will not provide services for the monetary benefit of any private entity and/or third-party organization.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Students Theatre Company (UTC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Students Theatre Company (UTC)
detailed_info.description: As an ensemble, we will focus on a different dramatist and a different acting method such as Stella Adler, Grotowski stay Stanislavski. We will examine texts from Oscar Wilde, Shakespeare and other classical theatre writers. We put on the shows for training purposes and for the purpose of making showreels to step into the acting industry career. We will coordinate show dates and workshops with dramatists, directors and actors in the theatre industry. There is a ten dollar membership fee which will be used to buy props and other necessary tools to run the club. We also do playwriting workshops which leads to a student written play being staged. This is a good opportunity for members to invite artistic directors to come and watch their shows to see their acting and their playwriting skills. These original plays will be chosen by votes from all of the members, Preferences are plays that will have enough characters for all of the club members to show their talents and skills. Meetings will be held regularly and members are expected to attend at least one of the two events each month and all of the rehearsals which will be scheduled after taking votes from all of the members. All of our performances will be recorded using a phone camera and will be shared with all of the members after gathering consent. This is a theatre company with a bright future, students will no longer have to wait four years to graduate in order to join an ensemble. University of Toronto will have its own theatre company which produces shows that its community wants and needs. We will learn the importance of team work in an ensemble, we will learn our own strengths and weaknesses, and we will find our inner artist together. Are you planning to step into the acting industry? Have you tried auditioning but you do not have the resources to get recognized? From Headshots to CV to showreels and self tapes. It can be overwhelming, but do not worry. We all have been there. This club aim to ease your journey into the acting and theatre industry.

The University of Toronto Students’ Union (UTSU) represents approximately 40,000 full-time undergraduate, professional faculty students on the St. George campus of the University of Toronto. UTSU’s mission is to serve and represent the full-time undergraduate students at the University of Toronto in order to ensure the best possible undergraduate experience.

UTSM designs, builds, and races super-efficient vehicles to compete in the Shell Eco-marathon Americas Competition. We prioritize sustainable energy by specializing in both Electric and Hydrogen powered vehicles to remain at the forefront of energy innovation. New members may join one of our divisions: Mechanical, Electrical, Powertrain, or Aerostructural on our Urban Concept team (hydrogen) or our Prototype team (electric). We welcome students from all backgrounds to join us in learning how to redefine fuel efficiency!

club_info.name: University of Toronto Sustainable Finance & Economics Club (SFEC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Sustainable Finance & Economics Club (SFEC)
detailed_info.description: The goal is to connect people and educate about themes related to sustainable finance and economics, such as market-based solutions to environmental issues, policies, and energy problematics. To do so, the idea is to host both social and formal events (ranging from pub nights to conferences), while sharing values of inclusiveness, acceptance, and will to discover and share ideas.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Table Tennis Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Table Tennis Club
detailed_info.description: The goal of the University of Toronto Table Tennis Club is to promote awareness of the sport and to provide a place for competitive and non-competitive players to convene. The UTTTC encourages players of all skill levels to participate and aims to help them improve their skill level through weekly practices and intramural league/tournaments throughout the programming year.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Tabletop Gaming Club (UTTGC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Tabletop Gaming Club (UTTGC)
detailed_info.description: UofT’s largest tabletop gaming club. We do board, card, miniature war, and role-playing games (examples include Coup, Magic, Warhammer 40K, and Dungeons & Dragons). We host regular events on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, as well as monthly specials. The club is open to everyone, even those not affiliated with the University of Toronto.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Taekwondo Student Organization

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Taekwondo Student Organization
detailed_info.description: TaeKwonDo has its roots in Korea but it has evolved into the quick paced martial art that is practiced globally. UTTO is a fantastic way for those interested in the art of Taekwondo to get together and practice their skills, perfect their technique and master new kicks. We hold classes for all skill levels starting at an introductory level and going all the way for classes held for competitive sparring. During the regular Fall/Winter semester, the club has approximately 50 beginner/intermediate students and 20 competitive team members. The U of T Taekwondo Team is an unofficial club team that has had a lot of success at tournaments both in and out of province. In April 2009, U of T clinched the Ontario Universities Taekwondo Competitive League (OUTCL) inter-collegiate tournament, coming in first place overall. In November 2009, the U of T Taekwondo Team competed in Master Chong’s World Class Taekwondo Tournament at Buffalo State College in Buffalo, N.Y., UTTO’s first international competition. The competitive team has competed in OUTCL tournaments and many local tournaments organised by the Ontario Taekwondo Association in the past years. In 2016, UTTO organised the University League, a chance for students to spar students from other university clubs. UTTO is not only about learning and practising Taekwondo. UTTO organises numerous social events throughout the year, including pub nights, board breaking seminar, and our annual trip to Hart House Farm as a way to get to know fellow UTTO members and create a mini-UTTO family.

The focus of the U of T Tennis Club is to PROMOTE the sport of tennis. The club offers a setting for the students and faculty of the university to share their love for tennis. We strive to offer members an opportunity to play tennis, improve their game, and overall enjoy the experience. Both competitive and recreational tennis exists among the weekly practice sessions and seasonal tournaments offered, providing an avenue for people of all levels to join.

UofT Tetris Club is intended to help UofT students who play Tetris meet, socialize, and game with each other. We aim to introduce more students to Tetris by hosting weekly in-person meetings, online tournaments, and Toronto LANs. Our club welcomes players of all skill levels, and we hope to provide support for newer players in our Discord server, with links to resources and channels for players to ask veteran players for help.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Thai Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Thai Student Association
detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Thai Student Association (UTTSA) is a cultural group which purpose is to promote the diversity of culture at the University of Toronto. Our goals are to provide assistance to Thai students and community members of University of Toronto, and to promote Thai culture in various areas such as Thai Boxing, Thai food, and tourist attractions.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Toastmasters Student Chapter

detailed_info.description: University of Toronto Toastmasters (UTT) is a club that is aimed at creating a supportive environment where anyone can improve their public speaking and leadership skills. The club began in 2004, beginning life as University of Toronto Engineering Toastmasters. Since then, UTT has expanded to help hundreds of students and professionals alike rise above their fears, realize their dreams, grow into incredible speakers, and live as stronger leaders. Currently, our club meets for regular meetings once a week, where members present and give feedback on prepared and impromptu speeches. We also plan special events several times per semester, for instance, promotional open houses and speaking competitions. All members enjoy the benefits of the various opportunities to speak during meetings and meet new people. Members also have the chance to pay for access to Toastmasters International’s Pathways, an education programme with different “paths” for members to hone different aspects of their public speaking. The club is very proud of the environment it creates, one that is supportive and positive, with peer evaluations focused on collective growth.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Trading Card Game Club (UOFTCGC)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Trading Card Game Club (UOFTCGC)
detailed_info.description: YuGiOh, Magic, Pokemon, we support them all, the UOFTCGC strives to be the final destination on your quest for trading card game gameplay on both UTM and UTSG campus. Our goal is to establish a student led safe space for students with no upfront membership fee.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Underwater Exploration Team (UTUX)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Underwater Exploration Team (UTUX)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto Underwater Exploration Team (UTUX) is a student-led design team dedicated to foster innovation and hands-on learning in the field of underwater robotics. Through the design, construction, and operation of Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs), we aim provide students with invaluable engineering experience, empowering them to push technological boundaries and contribute to real-world solutions. Our mission is to conduct underwater surveys, collect diverse samples, and collaborate with University of Toronto labs, ultimately advancing the field of underwater exploration and research.

Our goal: 1) To build and organize the community of Valorant players at the University of Toronto. 2) To run a competitive ladder and social events for the benefit of our members. 3) To help connect students with a support-network of peers who share common interests in computer gaming. 4) To compete in collegiate leagues

The University of Toronto Venture Club is a student organization founded and operated by a group of innovative and entrepreneurial-minded students. We are proud to be the first innovation and venture capital organization established by students in the history of the University of Toronto. Our mission is to support aspiring entrepreneurs at the University of Toronto, helping them to develop and realize their business ideas. We provide a platform for members to network, share resources, and exchange ideas with like-minded individuals. We believe in the power of innovation and the importance of collaboration and we strive to equip our members with the tools they need to succeed.

club_info.name: University of Toronto Vietnamese Students’ Association (UTVSA)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Vietnamese Students’ Association (UTVSA)
detailed_info.description: NA

club_info.name: University of Toronto Women’s Student Association

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto Women’s Student Association
detailed_info.description: Our mission is to equip self-identifying women with effective resources and empower them to tackle their goals. Our objectives include the following: Bring awareness to the social gaps and lack of opportunity in the professional industry for self-identifying women and provide a space to facilitate this conversation at the university level. Form a community wherein students can find a safe space to seek advice or support through our tailored programming while empowering members to seek out new experiences within and beyond post-secondary education. Educate and encourage the University of Toronto community to broaden their knowledge and practice allyship through participating in campaign initiatives and events which promote female empowerment.

club_info.name: University of Toronto, Let’s Eat Club

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto, Let’s Eat Club
detailed_info.description: Hey UofT, let’s eat! Our collective strives to create ways to creatively address food insecurity challenges many University of Toronto students experience. We aim to do this by providing affordable meal options to address the needs of students, whilst holding engaging fundraising events and socials that celebrate a central part of the human experience – food. We welcome new members that are passionate about targeting food insecurity.

club_info.name: University of Toronto’s Student Chapter of AISES (UofT AISES)

detailed_info.club_name: University of Toronto’s Student Chapter of AISES (UofT AISES)
detailed_info.description: The University of Toronto’s Student Chapter of AISES (UofT AISES) is a student group that aims to increase the representation of Indigenous peoples of North America in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) studies and careers. We will be attending the different regional, Canadian, and American AISES conferences held throughout the year. We also plan to host and attend different social and cultural events in Toronto. We hope to collaborate with other equity, diversity and inclusion groups on campus and within the engineering department.

The UofT Baking Club, established in 2020, is a welcoming social club for students who have a sweet tooth and a passion for baking. Our aim is to create a vibrant and inclusive community at UofT where individuals of all baking skill levels can come together, connect with like-minded peers, and form lasting friendships. Whether you’re a seasoned baker or just discovered your love for baking, we invite everyone to join us. Stay oven-fresh with us! Our club provides a platform for sharing recipes through our new Discord server: https://discord.gg/dxtqvKhkhK We offer a diverse range of activities, including baking workshops, friendly bake-offs, and themed events like Halloween cupcake decorating. Throughout the year, we also organize stress-relief events designed to bring joy and creativity to our members’ lives. Join us at UofT Baking Club, and together, we’ll expand our community while savouring the sweet taste of culinary delight!

club_info.name: UofT Blueprint Student Club, Technology for Nonprofits

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Blueprint Student Club, Technology for Nonprofits
detailed_info.description: Blueprint strives to make technology accessible and useful for those who create communities and promote public welfare. We’re a team of students that develops software pro bono for nonprofits and promotes technology for social good. Through Blueprint, members will build professional and social skills while contributing to their community.

A recreational group that adheres to the boxing standards and regulations set by Boxing Ontario. We aim to promote an active and healthy lifestyle through the sport of boxing. We will conduct training sessions or seminars to enrich our member’s understanding of the sport. Our activities will include technical training, strength and conditioning, and teaching knowledge about the sport. We believe that our club will provide a platform that enables our members to strengthen their mental fortitude as well as their physical conditions.

club_info.name: UofT Career Path Navigational Network Club

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Career Path Navigational Network Club
detailed_info.description: Our mission is to provide all UofT students, regardless of background, major, or year of study, with job-seeking guidance, assisting them in career planning and expanding their professional and social networks, ensuring that every student feels represented and supported. Our slogan is: Every Path. Every Student. One Network.

We mainly target the Chinese graduate population at the University of Toronto as a sociocultural group. We welcome all students who are currently enrolled in or recently graduated from the School of Graduate Studies at the University of Toronto. Our mission is to enrich the experiences of all Chinese graduate students at the University of Toronto by providing various events that connect our members with the university community.

club_info.name: UofT Christian Group: Milestone Churches Campus Ministry Student Chapter

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Christian Group: Milestone Churches Campus Ministry Student Chapter
detailed_info.description: If you’re interested in learning about Christianity, God, or why Christians do what they do; this club is for you. The Downtown Bible Talk is a weekly Christian initiative involved in studying the Bible and getting to understand the doctrines and principles of Jesus; the “why” behind His sacrifice on the cross. It is a space where anyone is welcome to join, and discuss, question and explore their positionality within their own faith, religion and or worldviews. The club seeks to provide a safe space where members can explore and ask questions about their life or the life of a “disciple of Christ”.

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Computer Vision Club St George
detailed_info.description: This student community will facilitate discussions around Machine Learning and Computer Vision, the field of artificial intelligence that trains computers to interpret and understand the visual world. We are a special interest group in computer vision.

club_info.name: UofT Drama Coalition of Student Theatre

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Drama Coalition of Student Theatre
detailed_info.description: The Drama Coalition works to generate and promote interest in extracurricular theatre at the University of Toronto and to foster relationships between the various dramatic groups and societies. The Drama Coalition strives to represent and connect all colleges and groups across UofT’s campuses as well as provide a convenient landing place to provide anyone interested with information on auditions, backstage opportunities, upcoming shows and more. The Drama Coalition is additionally responsible for the University of Toronto Drama Festival, a week of student written, directed, and performed theatre that is hosted by Hart House Theatre as well as organizing “The Dougies”, an end of year celebration to recognize students’ excellence in extracurricular theatre.
UofT Ebenezer is a Korean Christian organization for young people to learn God’s Word, be faithful in prayer, and have a time of worship and fellowship during the academic year.

We are the University of Toronto Film Club (UofTFC), a community committed to fostering a passionate and well-informed network of film enthusiasts and aspiring filmmakers across all disciplines. Our mission is to enrich the student experience through various avenues, including film screenings, discussions, hands-on workshops, and collaborative production projects. By offering this multifaceted platform, we aim to facilitate intellectual and creative growth, paving the way for developing the next generation of filmmakers, critics, and engaged film consumers. Whether you’re a seasoned filmmaker, a film studies major, or someone who loves watching movies, UofTFC provides an inclusive and dynamic space for learning, discussing, and creating film. We offer screenings, interactive discussions, practical filmmaking workshops, opportunities for collaborative projects, and networking events to connect members with industry professionals and like-minded peers.

Looking to join a supportive, positive community at the University? Look no further! The UofT Fitness Club is dedicated to creating a positive environment for all. If you want to participate in sports events, fitness events, social events and much more, make sure to join and connect with us on our socials!

We are simply aiming to spread our love of Formula 1 Racing and create a community where F1 fans at the University of Toronto can connect with each other, analyze races, and engage in healthy discussion about all that happens in the pinnacle of motorsport.

club_info.name: UofT Friendship, Academics, and Mental Wellness Alliance (FAM)

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Friendship, Academics, and Mental Wellness Alliance (FAM)
detailed_info.description: UofT FAM Alliance seeks to provide an inclusive and supportive community for all students at the University of Toronto by providing study sessions, friendship and team-building activities, as well as a non-judgmental space for students to express themselves in a positive way. This organization is a student group that aims to support students through their academic achievements and mental well-being.

The UofT Greens is a student campus club affiliated with the Young Greens of Ontario, a youth wing of the Green Party of Ontario. We seek to involve students in Green Party politics and sustainability efforts on campus and in the GTA through volunteering, events, and other community organizing. Our goals center around ensuring a just transition and fighting for comprehensive sustainability and intersectional feminism. We hope to help shape and promote Party policy and elect candidates to the House of Commons, Legislative Assembly, and Community Council! We will work towards these goals by hosting events and running campaigns with Green Party representatives, allied campus organizations, provincial and national organizations, local businesses, and other structures.

The UofT Blood Services team’s purpose is to raise awareness on the growing need of healthy blood donors in the Toronto area and encourage the UofT campus community to donate blood. This will be done by booths/events where we will help educate people about and promote blood donations.
A group of comedy muggles and magicians that teach and perform magic for the general public and each other. A place to learn more, and perform more.

Welcome to the University of Toronto Marathon Club! We invite all UofT students to join us. Whether you’ve always wanted to walk or run a 5K, 10K, half marathon, or full marathon, we’re here to help you reach your finish line. Led by students from the Faculty of Kinesiology and Physical Education, we use our expertise to support fellow UofT students in beginning or continuing their fitness journey and running towards longevity. There is passion in every pace, come train with us year-round and achieve your fitness goals this academic year.

The University of Toronto ML Wealth Management Club is a dynamic and forward-thinking student organization dedicated to exploring the applications of Machine Learning in the realm of Wealth Management and Finance. Our mission is to equip members with the knowledge, skills, and networking opportunities needed to excel in this exciting and rapidly evolving field. An example of a project being worked on include applying ML techniques to classic valuation models such as DCF, DDM, and comparable companies.

The UofT Mystery Club provides a platform for students to indulge their inner detective. Join us for a variety of mystery-related activities such as escape rooms, murder mystery games, movie & board game nights, and more!

The UofT Nuclear Energy Student Association’s (UTNESA) mission is to spark student interest in all aspects of nuclear energy. We seek to host events such as lectures, colloquiums, trips, and workshops where students can learn about current developments and contemporary issues in nuclear energy from research and industry professionals, expand their professional networks and see nuclear science being applied with workshops & trips to nuclear plants!

The Open Air Minds Club is a space for reconnection with nature and a break from the busy technological world. We strive to create an environment where the UofT community can relax and find a moment of calm in the natural world. In this club, we organize times to meet outdoors to allow our members to meet as a group and experience nature together. By doing so, we create both a deeper social bond, while allowing our minds a moment to relax.

Our goal is to make a significant impact in our community by raising awareness of several social issues, including homelessness, hunger, and addiction. One of the things we’re hoping to do is to bring in community leaders (i.e, people who run shelter homes, rehabilitation centres, or food banks) to share their first hand experiences on a particular social issue, and to then educate us on the best way we can support them. An example of this could involve deploying a team to volunteer with the organization for several days, or alternatively, organizing fundraisers to support the cause through monetary contributions or item donations. We were motivated to develop this initiative in response to the significant rise in homelessness and other hardships experienced by Torontonians due to the recent increase in cost of living.

Our world has become more technology-oriented than ever. A technical gap has widened for people who preserve wonderful ideas. In other words, it has become harder than ever to carry out projects as virtually anything requires technical expertise such as Machine Learning and software development. Our club tries to fill this technical gap by connecting people with ideas with people who preserve technical expertise. Unlike most clubs that do networking events, we plan to carry out actual projects.

The University of Toronto Quantum Computing club serves to bring the UofT Quantum Computing community together as well as introduce Quantum Computing to all who are interested. As a rich resource hub and a professional development group, we provide seminars, talks, and crash courses introducing academia to the general undergraduate community. We also operate as an organized team for competing in related hackathons and coding competitions. Moreover, there are intraclub projects emulating a research-group-like environment to foster research ability and vision. Students of all backgrounds are encouraged to join and learn with us from |0> up.

UofT Reads is a book club open to all students and members of the University of Toronto community! We strive to explore a variety of literary genres, cultivate thoughtful discussions and expand our intellectual horizons, and foster a welcoming and considerate environment.

club_info.name: UofT Real Estate knowledge Club (R-estate – UTREC)

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Real Estate knowledge Club (R-estate – UTREC)
detailed_info.description: The Toronto real estate market is a foreign area to many with limited knowledge to outsiders. Therefore, the UofT Real Estate Club aims to equip UofT students with basic knowledge regarding real estate transactions (renting an apartment and more), meet other UofT students to find a roommate, discuss the market and current events in the real estate world. All to provide information and/or confidence when it is time to search for a place to live.

club_info.name: UofT Research Insights and Schloarly Sharing Club

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Research Insights and Schloarly Sharing Club
detailed_info.description: RISS aims to provide resources for curious students interested in research. Members will participate in interdiciplinary discussions via biweekly journal clubs, where they present papers of interest from various academic areas. Additionally, an annual panel will be held to share research opportunities across different departments in UofT. The goal of RISS is to enhance members’ presentation skills, build their CV/resume, and support their academic journey. We aspire to foster an inclusive, supportive community where everyone can share their academic enthusiasm, interests, and resources with one another.

An official running club for all members of the University of Toronto community. Non-UofT students also welcome. All runners of all paces welcome. No one left behind. There is no pre-registration. Weekly runs will be hosted throughout the semester on Monday at 7:00 PM (5k), Wednesday at 7:00 PM (5k), and Thursday at 7:30 AM (5k). The runs will begin and end at the UC steps.

Welcome to the first-ever Sales & Trading Club at the University of Toronto! Our 3 core goals: ➡️ Build a network of like-minded UofT students passionate about Sales & Trading ➡️ Bridge the gap between students and finance corporations through multiple networking events each semester ➡️ Educate the public and our members on what Sales & Trading is all about

The UofT Splatoon Club is dedicated to creating a vibrant and fun community for Splatoon players on campus. Whether you’re an experienced cephalopod or a fresh squid on the block, we welcome you all the same!

The University of Toronto Student Seismic Design Team is an undergraduate organization that includes students from various programs such as civil engineering, architecture, computer engineering, computer science, and commerce. Our team is dedicated to promoting the study of earthquake engineering, and we strive to design and construct a high-quality tower to represent UofT at the annual Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (EERI) Seismic Design Competition.
UofT Students for Choice is a pro-choice student organization at the University of Toronto, advocating for an individual’s right to make autonomous decisions about their own body.

The UofT Telugu Students’ Organization serves as a forum where Telugu students, and students affiliated with the Telugu language, culture and heritage, can come together to organize and participate in various events and projects. While the goal of the TSO is to promote Telugu culture and language within the U of T Community, it also aims to provide opportunities to bring both Telugus and non-Telugus together.

Tempo Volleyball Club (TVC) is a volleyball club that provides casual volleyball drop-ins, socials, volleyball skill clinics, and competitive tournaments (with cash prizes!) for all skill levels and backgrounds. We strive to create a vibrant, safe and inclusive community at the University of Toronto St. George Campus, bringing together people interested in volleyball. We aspire to healthily promote different deviations and cultural styles of volleyball (5-1 coed, 4-2 coed, Reverses, 6s, 4s, Beach, Grass, Chinese 9-man) to a fresh audience of new players and veterans alike!

club_info.name: UofT Undergraduate Research Students’ Association (UofT URSA)

detailed_info.club_name: UofT Undergraduate Research Students’ Association (UofT URSA)
detailed_info.description: We are a community of undergraduate students passionate about all things research. We celebrate and highlight these opportunities in our university and beyond to fellow peers via running interactive seminars/panels, research conferences, field trips, lab tours, community outreach activities and more, as well as collaborating with other student associations, organizations, and academic research groups. As the largest UofT student organization centered around undergraduate research, we strive to provide a platform and voice for all current and future undergraduate researchers, connect them with experts who are leading their research fields, and be an inclusive space for beginning researchers. Through our efforts, we hope to bring our love of research and give advice to incoming and current university students, provide an understanding of what being a “researcher” means and how to navigate the challenges along the way, and be advocates who are breaking down barriers to and within the world of undergraduate research.

UofT Zine Club holds events, talks, workshops and casual meetups around zines and DIY culture. This encompasses artist multiples, small press, guerilla publishing, comics/cartooning, fan culture, print ephemera, experimental forms of writing, and more. UofT Zine Club advocates for the fair compensation of artists’ labour and the artistic and academic value of zines. Seasoned zinesters and curious onlookers alike are welcome to play, create, and learn with us! Normally we meet monthly on a last weekday evening, in North Borden room 106.

Hi! Are you a pre-vet student or someone who is passionate about animal welfare? Join the Veterinary Medicine Club (VMC), and connect with a community that supports aspiring veterinarians and animal enthusiasts at U of T! Throughout the year, we hold application info sessions with veterinary schools, collaborate with local welfare groups and organize a variety of other fun, animal-centred events. We aim to help our members gain valuable insights into the veterinary field, meet like-minded U of T students, and actively contribute to the well-being of animals and the environment!

UofTHacks Student Organization is Canada’s first ever student-run hackathon. Our purpose is to host an annual hackathon where over 500 innovators, developers, designers, and entrepreneurs participate in a 36-hour competition with both virtual and in-person events. During this event, they build unique and impactful projects. We exist to serve as a bridge between students, prospective employers, and professionals in the field. Our hackathon allows students to build valuable skills, gain experience, all while networking, and furthering their journey in technology. We aim to inspire the new generation of entrepreneurs by providing ample support from a professional community. Our objective is to host a successful hackathon, which students can use as a space to meet like-minded individuals who can further their careers.

At UofTrees, we are dedicated to fostering a culture of sustainability both on campus and in the wider community. Through initiatives like tree planting and waste reduction, we are committed to positively impacting the environment. Our mission is to cultivate a greener, more sustainable future for everyone. UofTrees is focused on promoting ecological and general sustainability. We raise awareness about how sustainability can be incorporated into everyday life and organize events that not only highlight these efforts but also provide a welcoming, relaxed space where students can unwind, socialize, and make new friends!

The Urban Studies Program at the University of Toronto aims to provide students with a multitude of lenses through which to observe, interpret, and understand urban life. The Urban Studies Student Union (URSSU) is the student union representing those in the Urban Studies Program and is a part of the larger Arts and Science Student Union (ASSU). Its executive is composed of elected undergraduate students who organize urban-focused academic and social events, provide peer support, and raise awareness about urban issues.

We are a dedicated group of University of Toronto students committed to supporting high school students, especially those from diverse backgrounds, as they navigate the complex university application process. Our mission is to demystify university admissions, providing personalized guidance and resources to ensure all students have the tools they need to succeed.

UTChinese Network is a not-for-profit organization led by Chinese students and young professionals in Canada. Founded in the Summer of 2006 and headquartered at the University of Toronto in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, our Mission is “to build the best platform for students to interact and to express themselves in relation to ideas, arts, and culture, as well as to create the best value for their lives, their academic endeavors, and their future careers”. We organize some of the largest events at the university focusing on three areas: Art & Culture, Career & Academic, and Social & Other.

The UofT Bhangra Club at St. George Campus that strives to connect those with a shared passion for Punjabi dance as well as to promote multiculturalism. We aim to positively influence our community, perform, and spread our love for dance along the way. Bhangra is a an upbeat, Indian folk dance that has become increasingly popular in many universities. During the semester, our performance team practices a set composed of many songs for one or two final showcases. We also have the option of attending workshops for general members that are limited on time.

The UTSG Cricket Club organizes cricket-related events on campus, both indoors and outdoors. We maintain liaison with the university and external teams to facilitate tournaments and series both on and off campus. Our activities range from practice sessions and friendly matches to competitive tournaments, promoting the spirit of cricket within the university community. We aim to create an inclusive environment where students of all skill levels can enjoy and participate in the sport, fostering teamwork, sportsmanship, and a sense of community.

detailed_info.club_name: UTSG MEDLIFE Student Chapter St George
detailed_info.description: MEDLIFE’s mission is to build a worldwide Movement empowering the poor in their fight for equal access to healthcare, education, and a safe home. To achieve this mission, MEDLIFE takes a different approach to social justice work: listening, collaborating, prioritizing sustainability, and always following up. As a student chapter, we aim to motivate undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Toronto to provide essential support to MEDLIFE. We host fundraisers to provide support for MEDLIFE Fund Projects, increase student participation on Service Learning Trips to support the Mobile Clinics and community development projects, and hold informational seminars.

The purpose of Project Sunshine is to bring passionate student volunteers together to spark joy and deliver smiles in pediatric patients facing various medical challenges. Our student volunteers will help restore a sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment. UTSG Project Sunshine Student Chapter offers Sending Sunshine, Hospital Programming, and Remote Programming. Sending Sunshine involves delivering surgi dolls (to help children understand their medical procedures and serve as their companions throughout their medical journey), therapeutic activity kits, toys, and much more. Hospital Programming includes caregiver wellness events, arts & crafts, and many activities and special events. The Remote Programming is done on an online platform providing various educational and recreational games appropriate for specific age groups. All of our offerings promote creativity, self-expression, socialization, and learning. Most importantly, we ensure that the pediatric patient’s childhood remains a time of wonder, especially during emotionally and physically challenging times, while providing caregivers the resources to de-stress.

The UTSG Tamil Students’ Association serves as a forum where Tamil students, and students affiliated with the Tamil language, culture and heritage, can come together to organize and participate in various events and projects. Whilst, the goal of the TSA is to promote Tamil culture and language within the U of T Community, it also aims to provide opportunities to bring both Tamils and non-Tamils together.

club_info.name: Varsity Mock Trial Undergraduate Student Team (VMT)

detailed_info.club_name: Varsity Mock Trial Undergraduate Student Team (VMT)
detailed_info.description: The Varsity Mock Trial team is an undergraduate mock trial team that aims to provide a comprehensive, diverse, and law-focused learning experience. Varsity Blues Mock fosters a healthy, competitive team environment, and will represent the University of Toronto honourably at various international and domestic mock trial tournaments, specifically in the U.S. and across Canada. Participating in mock trial is a useful experience for any student. It strengthens critical thinking, argumentation, and writing skills, which are valuable for all students regardless of their background or aspiring career path. Beyond competing, our mock trial team aims to help students develop and expand upon valuable skills, such as communication, teamwork, and perseverance. We aim to provide a community to encourage networking with hard-working, dedicated, like-minded students and legal professionals. Our team is structured like a law firm with managing and senior partners, associate and junior attorneys, testimony analysts, as well as paralegals. This ensures a wide range of roles and positions to make our team accessible and welcome to a diverse group of students looking to get involved in pre-law activities.

Canada’s largest student newspaper, The Varsity publishes print issues weekly on Mondays during the school year, and throughout the week online at thevarsity.ca through the full year including summers. It is distributed on all three of the University of Toronto’s campuses. Located on the second and third floors of 21 Sussex Ave. (behind Robarts Library), we are committed to covering the U of T Campus and environs and the issues important to you as students and citizens. Our news coverage is, without a doubt, the most complete on campus. We’re also a friendly bunch. Really. Anyone can work for the Varsity, and we encourage you to stop in at our office to take a look around. You don’t need anything but the desire to put in a little time: there are no tests, no writer’s fees, and, we hope, no hassles. Visit thevarsity.ca/volunteer to learn more about how you can get involved. We are published by Varsity Publications Inc., a non-profit corporation financed in part by an annual levy paid by all full-time undergraduates. The Varsity will not publish material attempting to incite violence or hatred towards particular individuals or an identifiable group, particularly on the basis of race, national or ethnic origin, colour, gender, age, mental or physical disability, or sexual orientation. Now in its 140th year, The Varsity is looking for new writers, photographers, illustrators, print designers, web developers, cartoonists, and copy-editors to help continue its tradition as U of T’s unofficial school of journalism.

At the Vertige Investment Group (VIG), we believe that proactivity is paramount to excellence. That is why our research is focused on combining traditional analysis and innovative strategies in an effort to bridge the gap between today and tomorrow. Founded in 2024, the Vertige Investment Group is a University of Toronto-based student organization dedicated to publishing industry-grade macroeconomic and equity market insights, alongside the development of artificial intelligence-driven quantitative strategies and algorithmic trading models. Sustainability is emphasized through environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives, in an effort to ensure that our world tomorrow is just as bright as our world today. The Vertige Investment Group’s Analyst Program is an annual initiative focused on turning passionate and ambitious students into competent, highly specialized analysts in their respective fields. Graduates of the Analyst Program will be offered a position in Vertige Research where their work will be published through Vertige Investment Group’s public channels. Finally, Vertige Investment Group is the manager of The Vertige Fund, a private investment portfolio focused on applying the group’s strategies and research in capturing alpha through relative value-based approaches.
The VCAA organizes all the athletic activities offered by the University of Toronto intramurals program for Vic students. We also hold special events to promote an interest in athletics at Vic.

Victoria University Students’ Administrative Council is the student government at Victoria University in the University of Toronto. We are an elected body who are here to represent the many different areas of student interest at Victoria.

Vision Innovation Group is a passionate community of students who share a love for airsoft’s tactical intensity and the excitement of crafting gears that elevates the game to new heights. Whether you’re a seasoned airsoft veteran or just someone who is fond of the sport, our club is the place where your interests will flourish. We will organize routine airsoft events, and provide a platform for general discussions and tradings. Beyond that, we offer an opportunity for you to bring your innovational ideas to reality. Our design department will be focusing on improving existing gears, and creating new innovations.

The University of Toronto Visual Art Club (UTVAC or VAC) aims to build an encouraging, artistic community and a positive platform for students interested in art to develop and express their passion through art workshops, exhibits, and socials. We believe that anyone can enjoy art regardless of medium or skill level, and we hope to inspire students who may be hesitant about art to discover their creative potentials.

Volunteer Interpretation Service for Koreans (VISK) provides students at the University of Toronto with opportunities to interpret North/South Koreans in the Greater Toronto Area (GTA). We connect English/Korean-speaking students to interpret various services within GTA including medical and social services. This is a great experience and opportunity for students from various programs of study to utilize their knowledge outside of the classroom and communication skills to help North/South Koreans in real-life situations. To be part of the club, students must have fluent communicative skills in both English and Korean. We invite all students with these requirements enrolled at the University of Toronto to be a part of VISK.

club_info.name: Volunteer Organization of Korean Life-Science Students (VOKLS)

detailed_info.club_name: Volunteer Organization of Korean Life-Science Students (VOKLS)
detailed_info.description: The Volunteer Organization of Korean Life-Science Students (VOKLS) is a professional student organization dedicated to fostering academic excellence and promoting interpersonal growth among Korean Life-Science students. Through a wide range of activities, including academic seminars, fundraising sales, and volunteering events, VOKLS strives to establish a supportive network that enhances both the academic and cultural experiences of its members. By fostering positive social changes, we aim to empower our members to become visionary leaders, extending their impact beyond the confines of our campus and making a meaningful difference in the world.
This organization’s mission is to promote civic engagement by educating American students on registering to vote and securing their absentee ballots while living in Canada.

The Web Development Club is a student run tutorial style club dedicated in teaching interested members of the U of T community the fundamentals of Web Development. Each member is directly involved in Web Development projects. Past experiences with Web Development is not required.

WISA is a club that celebrates the vast and vibrant culture of all the countries and territories that make up the Caribbean and its diaspora. We intend to be your home away from home to all those who call the West Indies home and heritage. WISA hosts social and academic events that aim at achieving a unique and open cultural experience for West Indian students and all students who have a love for Caribbean culture at the University of Toronto St. George. Past events have included picnics, study halls, parties, movie nights, a market and showcase for Caribbean talent and more… So no matter where you are from, we invite you to come join us at any of our events as we celebrate unity, diversity and Caribbean excellence.

A campus club dedicated to promoting Wing Chun Kung Fu to the U of T community. Wing Chun is a traditional Chinese martial art invented by a woman around 300 years ago, with the single goal of defending oneself in the minimum time, using minimum energy, yet with maximum effectiveness. Wing Chun is not a sport, but it will equip you with the confidence & skills needed to face ‘real fight’ situations.

club_info.name: Women and Gender Studies Students’ Union (WGSSU)

detailed_info.club_name: Women and Gender Studies Students’ Union (WGSSU)
detailed_info.description: WGSSU acts as a source of information & support for University of Toronto students, working to combine student activism with academic studies. The WGSSU at the University of Toronto provides students with the opportunity to develop friendships, work relationships, and a strong academic learning environment. Each year, the WGSSU organizes several events, both academic and social, for the undergraduate student body in Women & Gender Studies.

club_info.name: Women in Computer Science Student Association (WiCS)

detailed_info.club_name: Women in Computer Science Student Association (WiCS)
detailed_info.description: To create a positive space on campus for all genders and sexual orientations by accepting everyone who wants to join our group, and conducting meetings and other events. To create a social support network for self-identified women in computer science programs and courses at the University of Toronto, St George Campus by conducting meeting and other social events.
